{{EngvarB|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox games | Name = 6th Southeast Asian Peninsular Games | Host city = [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] | Logo = | Size = 120px | Optional caption = | Sports = 15 | Nations participating = 7 | Athletes participating = | Opening ceremony = 6 December | Closing ceremony = 13 December | Officially opened by = [[Abdul Halim of Kedah]]
{{small|[[Yang di-Pertuan Agong|King]]}} of [[Malaysia]] | Athlete's Oath = | Judge's Oath = | Torch lighter = | Ceremony venue = [[Stadium Merdeka]] | next = [[1973 Southeast Asian Peninsular Games|1973]] | previous = [[1969 Southeast Asian Peninsular Games|1969]] }} The '''1971 [[Southeast Asian Games|Southeast Asian Peninsular Games]]''', officially known as the '''6th Southeast Asian Peninsular Games''', was a Southeast Asian multi-sport event held in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] from 6 to 13 December 1971 with 15 sports featured in the games. In this edition of the games, host country Malaysia joined Singapore in pressuring Thailand to let the SEAP Games Federation expand to include the [[Philippines]] and [[Indonesia]], but to no avail. Thai officials felt that such expansion would be contrary to the small family affair they had intended the games to be, and would not be in keeping with the close-neighbours spirit the games was supposed to cultivate.[[Percy Seneviratne]] (1993) ''Golden Moments: the S.E.A Games 1959-1991'' [[Dominie Press]], [[Singapore]] {{ISBN|981-00-4597-2}} This was the second time Malaysia hosted the games and its first time since [[1965 Southeast Asian Peninsular Games|1965]]. The games was opened and closed by Abdul Halim, the King of Malaysia at the Stadium Merdeka. The final medal tally was led by Thailand, followed by host Malaysia and Singapore. ==The games== ===Participating nations=== {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| * {{flag|Burma|1948}} * {{flag|Khmer Republic}} * {{flag|Laos|1952}} * {{MAS}} * {{SIN}} * {{flag|South Vietnam|1890}} * {{THA}} }} ===Sports=== {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| * {{GamesSport|Aquatics}} * {{GamesSport|Athletics|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Badminton|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Basketball|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Boxing|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Cycling|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Football}} * {{GamesSport|Hockey|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Judo|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Sepak Takraw|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Shooting|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Table tennis|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Tennis|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Volleyball|Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Weightlifting|Format=m}} }} ===Aquatics=== '''[[Aquatic sports|Aquatics]]''' included [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]], [[Diving (sport)|diving]] and [[water polo]] events. The three sports of aquatics were held in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]]. Aquatics events was held between 12 December to 15 December. ====Swimming==== {{collapse top|title=Men's events}} {| {{MedalistTable|type=Event|columns=2}} |- |100 m freestyle |{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Tan Thuan Heng]]||57.05 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Tan Bun Thay]]||57.43 |{{flagicon|Myanmar|1974}} [[Aung Hlain Win]]||59.25 |- |200 m freestyle |{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Tan Thuan Heng]]||2:07.10 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Tan Bun Thay]]||2:08.54 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Eat Kim Heng]]||2:09.90 |- |400 m freestyle |{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Tan Thuan Heng]]||4:41.82 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Eat Kim Heng]]||4:43.40 |{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Liew Chun Wei]]||4:43.40 |- |1500 m freestyle |{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Liew Chun Wei]]||18:43.55 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Tan Bun Thay]]||18:58.98 |{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Mark Chan]]||18:59.61 |-bgcolor=#DDDDDD |colspan=7| |- |100 m backstroke |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Van Sarun]]||1:04.96 |{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Alex Chan (swimmer)|Alex Chan]]||1:06.65 |{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Chiang Jin Choon]]||1:06.72 |- |200 m backstroke |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Van Sarun]]||2:20.34 |{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Chiang Jin Choon]]||2:24.77 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Hem Thon]]||2:28.49 |-bgcolor=#DDDDDD |colspan=7| |- |100 m breaststroke |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Phat Sin Onn]]||1:10.84 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Ung Meng Tay]]||1:12.31 |{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Khong Kok Sun]]||1:14.12 |- |200 m breaststroke |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Phat Sin Onn]]||2:38.04 |{{flagicon|Khmer Republic}} [[Yi Sokhon]]||2:43.13 |{{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Alan R. {{TennisEventInfo|2009|San Luis Potosí Challenger| | date=April 6 – April 12 | edition=19th | location=[[San Luis Potosí]], [[Mexico]] | champs={{flagicon|COL}} [[Santiago Giraldo]] | champd={{flagicon|MEX}} [[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]] / {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Horacio Zeballos]] | after_year=2012 }}
The '''2009 [[San Luis Potosí Challenger]]''' was a professional [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Tennis court#Clay courts|outdoor red clay courts]]. It was part of the [[2009 ATP Challenger Tour]]. It took place in [[San Luis Potosí]], [[Mexico]] between 6 and 12 April 2009.
==Singles entrants== ===Seeds=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Nationality ! Player ! Ranking* ! Seeding |- | {{flag|ARG}} | [[Horacio Zeballos]] | 126 | 1 |- | {{flag|COL}} | [[Santiago Giraldo]] | 146 | 2 |- | {{flag|BRA}} | [[Franco Ferreiro]] | 155 | 3 |- | {{flag|ARG}} | [[Mariano Puerta]] | 205 | 4 |- | {{flag|COL}} | [[Alejandro Falla]] | 207 | 5 |- | {{flag|SUI}} | [[Michael Lammer]] | 219 | 6 |- | {{flag|MEX}} | [[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]] | 223 | 7 |- | {{flag|ITA}} | [[Paolo Lorenzi]] | 227 | 8 |} *Rankings are as of March 23, 2009.
===Other entrants=== The following players received wildcards into the singles main draw: * {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Luis Manuel Flores]] * {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Mariano Puerta]] * {{flagicon|MEX}} Manuel Sánchez * {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Mariano Zabaleta]]
The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|ECU}} [[Júlio César Campozano]] * {{flagicon|COL}} [[Juan Sebastián Cabal]] * {{flagicon|COL}} [[Alejandro González (tennis)|Alejandro González]] * {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Vincent Millot]]
==Champions== ===Men's singles=== {{main|2009 San Luis Potosí Challenger – Singles}} {{flagicon|COL}} '''[[Santiago Giraldo]]''' def. {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Paolo Lorenzi]], 6–2, 6–7(3), 6–2
===Men's doubles=== {{main|2009 San Luis Potosí Challenger – Doubles}} {{flagicon|MEX}} '''[[Santiago González (tennis)|Santiago González]]''' / {{flagicon|ARG}} '''[[Horacio Zeballos]]''' def. {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Franco Ferreiro]] / {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Júlio Silva]], 6–2, 7–6(5)

{{Use Australian English|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox award | name = AFL Women's best and fairest | image = | imagesize = | caption = | current_awards = | description = The [[best and fairest]] player in the [[AFL Women's]] | presenter = [[AFL Women's|AFLW]] | country = Australia | network = | location = [[Docklands Stadium]] | year = [[2017 AFL Women's best and fairest|2017]] | year2 = | holder = [[Emma Kearney (sportswoman)|Emma Kearney]] ({{AFLW WB}}) | website = [http://www.afl.com.au/womens/player-profiles/aflw-awards AFLW Player Awards] }}
The '''AFL Women's best and fairest''' is awarded to the [[best and fairest]] player in the [[AFL Women's]] (AFLW) during the home-and-away season, as determined by votes cast by the officiating [[Umpire (Australian rules football)|field umpires]] after each game. It is the most prestigious award for individual players in the AFLW. It is also widely acknowledged as the highest individual honour in the sport of [[women's Australian rules football]].
==Criteria==
===Voting procedure=== [[File:2017 AFL Grand Final parade – Erin Phillips.jpg|thumb|[[Erin Phillips]] was the inaugural winner of the award in 2017.]] To determine the ''best'' player, the three field umpires (not the goal umpires or boundary umpires) confer after each home-and-away match and award three votes, two votes and one vote to the players they regard as the best, second-best and third-best in the match, respectively. On the awards night, the votes from each match are tallied, and the player or players with the highest number of votes is awarded the trophy (subject to eligibility – see below).<ref name="awards">{{cite web|title=AFLW Player Awards|url=http://www.afl.com.au/womens/player-profiles/aflw-awards|work=afl.com.au|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref>
The current voting system, which is the same as that of the [[Australian Football League]] (AFL)'s [[Brownlow Medal]], has been used since the award's inception. If two or more eligible players score the equal highest number of votes, each wins a trophy.
===Ineligibility=== The ''fairest'' component of the trophy is achieved by making ineligible any player who is suspended by the AFL Tribunal during the home-and-away season. An ineligible player cannot win the award, regardless of the number of votes she has received.<ref name="awards"/>
A player remains eligible for the award under the following circumstances: * she is suspended during the finals or pre-season; * she serves a suspension in the current season which carried on from, or was earned for an offence committed in, the previous season; * she receives any sort of club-imposed suspension which is not recognised by the AFL Tribunal; * she is found guilty by the AFL Tribunal of an offence which attracts only a financial penalty.
Umpires cast their votes for each game independent of eligibility criteria of the players; ''i.e.'' umpires can cast votes for players who have already been suspended during that season if they perceive them to be amongst the best on the ground.
==Award ceremony== [[File:Etihad Stadium crop.jpg|thumb|[[Docklands Stadium]], current home of the W Awards Night]] The AFL Women's best and fairest is awarded during the W Awards Night, the official AFL Women's awards ceremony, following the [[AFL Women's Grand Final]]. The ceremony itself has become increasingly elaborate, with footballers and their dates gradually becoming more fashion-conscious, however it has a much smaller following in comparison to the Brownlow Medal ceremony. The ceremony is currently held at [[Docklands Stadium]] in Melbourne.<ref name="awards"/><ref>{{cite web|title=AFLW stars glam up: Best pics from W Awards coral carpet|url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/2017-03-28/aflw-stars-glam-up-best-pics-from-w-awards-red-carpet|work=afl.com.au|date=28 March 2017|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref>
==Winners== {{For|a list of winners|List of AFL Women's best and fairest winners}}
==Records== '''Winners who also won a premiership in same season''' * [[Erin Phillips]] ({{AFLW Ade}}, 2017) * [[Emma Kearney (sportswoman)|Emma Kearney]] ({{AFLW WB}}, 2018)
==See also== {{Portal|Australian rules football|Women's sport}} * [[Brownlow Medal]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://afl.com.au/womens Official AFL Women's website]

[[2011 European Youth Summer Olympic Festival]] | embedded = | website = }} '''Araklı Arena''' ({{lang-tr|Araklı Spor Salonu}}) is an indoor volleyball venue located in [[Araklı]] town of [[Trabzon Province]], [[Turkey]]. Built in 2006, the arena has a capacity of 500 spectators.{{cite web|url=http://www.trabzon-gsim.gov.tr/?p=Arakli-Spor-Salonu |publisher=Trabzon Valiliği-Gençlik ve Spor İl Müdürlüğü |title=Araklı Spor Salonu |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-07-20 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2007, the venue hosted the [[2007 Black Sea Games|1st Black Sea Games]].{{cite web |url=http://www.karadenizoyunlari.gov.tr/sayfalar/form/form_reglaman/Regleman-tr/voleybol.pdf |publisher=Karadeniz Oyunları |title=Voleybol Teknik Regleman-2007 Karadeniz Oyunları, Trabzon |language=Turkish |accessdate=2011-07-30 }} [[Volleyball at the 2011 European Youth Summer Olympic Festival|Volleyball matches for boys]] were played at this arena during the [[2011 European Youth Summer Olympic Festival]]. ==See also== * [[Araklı]] * [[World Trade Center Trabzon ]] * [[Trabzon Museum]] * [[Trabzon]] * [[Chepni people|Chepni]] * [[Pontic Greeks]] * [[Kadirga Festival]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arakli Arena}} [[Category:Sports venues in Trabzon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2006]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Turkey]] {{Turkey-sport-stub}} {{Volleyball-stub}}

[[Image:Barmy Army at the SCG.JPG|right|thumb|300px|The Barmy Army chanting at the Sydney Cricket Ground]]
The '''Barmy Army''' is a company limited by guarantee, registered in England and Wales. Its Registered address is Osbourne House, 143-145 Stanwell Road, Ashford, Middlesex TW15 3QN. The company provides tickets and arranges touring parties for some of its members to follow the [[English cricket team]] in the UK and overseas. The name is also applied to followers of the team who join in with match day activities in the crowd, but do not necessarily travel as part of an organised tour. The term "barmy" is English slang for "mad".
The group, then less organised, was given its name by the Australian media during the [[English cricket team in Australia in 1994-95|1994-1995]] [[Test cricket|Test]] series in [[Australia]], reportedly for the fans' hopeless audacity in travelling all the way to Australia in the near-certain knowledge that their team would lose, and the fact that they kept on chanting encouragement to the England team even when England were losing quite badly.<ref>Staff. [https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2006/dec/01/ashes2006.cricket7 Crass and corporate - why the Barmy Army are no laughing matter] 1 December 2006</ref><ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/dominic-lawson/dominic-lawson-fight-back-against-the-barmy-army-427134.html Dominic Lawson: Fight back against the Barmy Army], The Independent, 5 Dec 2006</ref> It was co-founded by [[Paul Burnham]].<ref name=itn />
==History== The Barmy Army, which is now a limited company, states that it wants to "make watching cricket more fun and much more popular". The group uses [[flag]]s, [[banner]]s, [[song]]s and [[chant]]s to encourage the team and crowd participation in their activities. In contrast to the reputations of some sports fans for [[hooliganism]], the Barmy Army organisers actively discourage and avoid such behaviour.
The group engages in [[Charitable organization|charity]] work and has gained a good reputation among most cricket administrators. However, many cricket followers find their constant chanting to be annoying and disruptive, particularly during the afternoon sessions of Test matches when the chanting of the Barmy Army, fuelled by their consumption of large amounts of alcohol, often becomes a repetitive, irritating background noise; among others, the renowned cricket writer/commentator [[Christopher Martin-Jenkins]] accused them of "demeaning English cricket".<ref>Christopher Martin-Jenkins. [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,426-1456636,00.html Vaughan's men reap dividends of bolder approach] [[The Times]], 26 January 2005</ref>
"Barmy Army" was a [[football chant]] sung by fans at many grounds, originally sung at Hillsborough by [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] in the early 1980s. This was because [[Howard Wilkinson]], known as Sergeant Wilko, who was manager at the time inspired the chant, "Sergeant Wilko's Barmy Army". In conjunction with the increasing appearance of English football shirts at cricket grounds in the early 1990s, the song's droning, repetitive cry of "Barmy Army, Barmy Army, Barmy Army" transferred to domestic Test cricket arenas at [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Old Trafford]] and [[Headingley Cricket Ground|Headingley]]. It was particularly apparent during the 1993 [[The Ashes|Ashes]] tour.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}<!--whole paragraph--> [[File:Barmy Army - The Gabba 2006.jpeg|200px|thumb|right|The Barmy Army and police at [[the Gabba]], November 2006.]]
Throughout the 1990s, increased spending power, via a stronger British Pound at the time, enabled fans to take the song overseas when following tours of the English national cricket team. Because of that particular song, and the fact that it seemed to represent English fans' activity of standing in the hot sun, drinking lager all day, until they were sunburnt and unwell, it became a description as well as a song. [[David Lloyd (cricketer)|David Lloyd]] and [[Ian Botham]] used the tag to describe the supporters whilst commentating for [[Sky Sports]] during England's tours from 1993 to 1995.
Only in the mid-1990s was the tag recognised as an official title for English touring cricket fans and adopted by what is now recognised as the official Barmy Army.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}<!--For the whole paragraph-->
In the late 1990s performers [[Richard Stilgoe]] and [[Peter Skellern]] recognised the need for an anthem for the loyal supporters of a team that regularly seemed to lose and wrote a stirring song called "The Barmy Army" which they included in their touring repertoire. It can be found on their 1999 CD "A Quiet Night Out" and humorously celebrates the English team's skill at "snatching defeat from the jaws of victory".
[[File:Billy the trumpeter.JPG|thumb|Trumpeter [[Billy Cooper (trumpeter)|Billy Cooper]] Cheering England at 1st Test vs Pakistan Dubai January 2012 ]] Most grounds now set aside areas especially for Barmy Army fans apart from [[Lord's]].<ref name=itn>{{cite web|url=http://www.inthenews.co.uk/news/not-barmy-just-lucky-$458673.htm |title=Not barmy, just lucky |publisher=Inthenews.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107193155/http://www.inthenews.co.uk/news/not-barmy-just-lucky-%24458673.htm |archivedate=7 January 2014 |df= }}</ref>
== In other sports == Supporters of English national teams in other sports are also subsidiaries of Barmy Army. The rugby equivalent was formed in 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/Barmy-Army-Rugby-360449967469632/|title=Barmy Army Rugby|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-27}}</ref>, they also form part of the Army to support [[British and Irish Lions]], while there is another separate subsidiary for Rugby League.

The '''Conconi Test''' is a [[sports medicine]] test<ref>{{cite journal|last=Conconi|first=Francesco|year=1982|title=Determination of the anaerobic threshold by a non-invasive field test in runners|journal=Journal of Applied Physiology|volume=52|pages=869–73|pmid=7085420|issue=4|author2=M. Ferrare|author3=P.G. Ziglio|display-authors=2|last4=Droghetti|first4=P|last5=Codeca|first5=L}}</ref> intended to measure an individual's maximum [[Anaerobic threshold|anaerobic]] and [[Aerobic threshold|aerobic]] threshold [[heart rate]]s.
The test measures a person's heart rates at different loads (e.g. faster speeds on a treadmill). The points are plotted on a graph with heart rate on one axis and power (or some correlated measurement such as running speed) on the other axis; the graph's deflection point indicates the [[aerobic threshold]]. The heart rate increases (approximately) linearly up to the deflection point, where the heart rate reaches AT (also known as LT, [[lactate threshold]], in more modern nomenclature). The test continues for a while, under increasing load, until the subject has gone well past the [[Anaerobic exercise#Anaerobic threshold|anaerobic threshold]].
==Accuracy== Two studies from the mid 90s<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Andrew M.|author2=Jonathan H. Doust|year=1995|title=Lack of reliability in Conconi's heart rate deflection point|journal=International Journal of Sports Medicine|volume=16|issue=8|pages=541–544|pmid=8776209|doi=10.1055/s-2007-973051}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Andrew M.|author2=Jonathan H. Doust|year=1997|title=The Conconi test is not valid for estimation of the lactate turnpoint in runners|journal=Journal of Sports Sciences|volume=15|issue=4|pages=385–394|doi=10.1080/026404197367173|pmid=9293415}}</ref> showed the Conconi test to be inaccurate and impractical in assessing the anaerobic threshold, while other recent studies are disputing or have disputed this contention,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Bourgois|first=Jan|author2=Coorevits, Pascal |author3=Danneels, Lieven |author4=Witvouw, Erik |author5=Cambier, Dirk |author6= Vrijens, Jacques |title=Validity of the heart rate deflection point as a predictor of lactate threshold concepts during cycling|journal=Journal of Strength & Conditioning Research|volume=18|issue=3|pages=498–503|doi=10.1519/1533-4287(2004)18<498:VOTHRD>2.0.CO;2|year=2004|issn=1533-4287}}</ref> and still others proposed modifications to improve the test.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sentija|first=D. |author2=V. Vucetic |author3=C. Markovic|year=2007|title=Validity of the Modified Conconi Running Test|journal=International Journal of Sports Medicine|volume=28|pages=1006–1011|doi=10.1055/s-2007-965071|pmid=17614011|issue=12}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Cardiac stress test]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} * Peak Performance - Issue 23

Center field: {{convert|404|ft}}
Right field: {{convert|305|ft}} }} '''Cooley Law School Stadium''' (previously known as '''Oldsmobile Park''') is a [[baseball stadium]] in [[Lansing, Michigan]], home field of the [[Lansing Lugnuts]] [[minor league baseball]] team. The [[Michigan State Spartans]] [[college baseball]] team also plays select home games at Cooley Law School Stadium. The stadium is situated in downtown Lansing in the Stadium District on a relatively narrow strip of land between and below [[Interstate 96 Business (Lansing, Michigan)|Larch and Cedar streets]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball]], though it has also hosted an ice skating rink, an outdoor movie theater, a haunted house, and served as a concert venue for the annual [[Common Ground Music Festival]]. Due to the dimensions of the city block in which the stadium was constructed, the right and left field fences 'notch' sharply into distances of {{convert|305|ft}} at each foul pole. ==History== The stadium replaced a block of storefronts along [[Capitol Loop|Michigan Avenue]]. Originally budgeted $10 million for construction, the construction costs rose slightly to $12.8 million.{{cite web |title=City of Lansing and Lugnuts Announce Exciting New Developments at Oldsmobile Park|url=http://www.lansinglugnuts.com/fan_action/101404.html|publisher=Minor League Baseball|date=October 14, 2004|accessdate=May 27, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041103204024/http://www.lansinglugnuts.com/fan_action/101404.html|archivedate=November 3, 2004 }} [[Groundbreaking]] for the stadium took place on April 3, 1995, and it was officially opened exactly one year later on April 3, 1996. Its first game was between the [[college baseball]] teams of the [[University of Michigan]] and [[Michigan State University]]. Two days later, the Lansing Lugnuts had their first game at the venue against the [[Rockford Cubbies]].{{cite web |title=Cooley Law School Stadium Facts|url=http://cooleylawschoolstadium.com/park-guide/stadium-facts|publisher=Cooley Law School Stadium|accessdate=May 27, 2008}} On February 22, 2010, Lansing mayor [[Virgil Bernero]] announced that the stadium would be renamed [[Western Michigan University Cooley Law School|Thomas M. Cooley Law School]] Stadium, a result of the park's new sponsorship agreement.{{cite news|title=Lugnuts Ballpark Soon Will be Cooley Law School Stadium |first=Melissa |last=Domsic |url=http://www.lansingstatejournal.com/article/20100222/NEWS01/2220338 |newspaper=[[Lansing State Journal]] |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=February 22, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In March 2010, Lansing-based [[Jackson National Life]] Insurance Company purchased the rights to name the field "Jackson Field" for 1 year. Thus, the full name of the venue is Jackson Field at Thomas M. Cooley Law School Stadium.{{cite news|title=Jackson National Lands Lugnuts Field Naming Rights|url=http://www.lansingstatejournal.com/article/20100322/NEWS03/303220002/Jackson-National-lands-Lugnuts-field-naming-rights|newspaper=[[Lansing State Journal]]|date=March 22, 2010|accessdate=March 22, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} On March 12, 2014, a $22 million renovation proposal for the stadium was announced named '''The Outfield'''. It would include $11 million in public bonds for renovation of the actual stadium structure including new turf, and updated locker rooms, concessions and new box seats. $11 million in additional private investments which would include 80 apartments, a year-round bar and grill, and a new scoreboard. The proposal also includes the city negotiating a new contract with the team which is proposed to bring in an additional 25% revenue for the city.{{cite news|last=Anders|first=Melissa|title=Living above the outfield: Lansing Lugnuts' stadium renovation plan includes apartments, restaurants|url=http://www.mlive.com/lansing-news/index.ssf/2014/03/lansing_lugnuts_apartments_bas.html|accessdate=24 March 2014|newspaper=MLive.com|date=12 March 2014}} ==Other uses== ===Rugby=== On October 19, 2018, the [[Michigan State Spartans#Rugby|Michigan State Spartans]] and [[Michigan Wolverines men's rugby|Michigan Wolverines]] had their rivalry match, the Battle for the Mitten, at Cooley Law School Stadium.https://www.fox47news.com/we-are-spartans/battle-for-the-mitten-field-transformation Michigan State defeated Michigan 25-15. ===Soccer=== On October 25, 2018, the newly planned [[Lansing Ignite FC|Lansing Ignite]] soccer team announced it would begin playing it's home games at the stadium. ==Field dimensions== *Left field: {{convert|305|ft}} *Left-center: {{convert|380|ft}} *Center field: {{convert|404|ft}} *Right-center: {{convert|412|ft}} *Right field: {{convert|305|ft}} ==Gallery== File:OldsmobilePark02.jpg|Cooley Law School Stadium view from the outfield ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.milb.com/index.jsp?sid=t499 Cooley Law School Stadium Website] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2006/Lansing/Lansing.htm Oldsmobile Park Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] {{Midwest League Ballparks}} {{Big Ten Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Michigan NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} {{Lansing-East Lansing}} [[Category:Sports venues in Lansing, Michigan]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Michigan]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Michigan]] [[Category:Michigan State Spartans baseball]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Michigan]] [[Category:USL League One stadiums]]

revision.text:
{{Chess diagram | tright |
|rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd|nd|rd |pd|pd|pd| | |pd|pd|pd | | | | | | | | | | | |pd| | | | | | | |pl| | | | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl |French Defense, Exchange Variation}} In [[chess]], an '''exchange variation''' is a type of [[chess opening|opening]] in which there is an early, voluntary exchange of pawns or pieces. Such variations are often quieter than other lines because the early release of tension minimizes the possibility of surprise tactics or sharp, forcing lines, particularly where it results in a symmetrical [[pawn structure]]. {{algebraic notation|pos=toc}}
==Intents and implications== [[White and Black in chess|White]] may choose an exchange variation as a relatively risk-free way to try to exploit White's [[First-move advantage in chess|first-move advantage]]. Players such as [[Mikhail Botvinnik]] and [[Yasser Seirawan]] used the Exchange Variation of the [[Slav Defense]] this way.
White may also play an exchange variation in an effort to draw the game. This approach is not without risks. [[International Master]] [[John L. Watson]] has written that in the Exchange Variation of the [[French Defense]], "Black can always make the struggle an unbalanced one if he chooses".<ref>John L. Watson, ''Play the French'', Pergamon Press, 1986, p. 28. {{ISBN|0-08-026929-X}}.</ref> Moreover, playing so blatantly for a draw may place a psychological burden on White: "White has already ceded the advantage of the first move, and he knows it, whereas Black is challenged to find ways to seize the initiative."<ref>Watson 1986, p. 29.</ref>
Not all exchange variations are quiet; the Exchange Variation of the [[Grunfeld Defence|Grunfeld Defense]] is regarded as one of White's sharpest and most aggressive options, since it allows White to build up a massive pawn center, which Black will try to undermine. The Exchange Variation of the [[Queen's Gambit Declined]] often involves attacks by one or both sides on the enemy king.
Exchange variations involving the exchange of pawns often lead to symmetrical central pawn structures, as in the Slav Defense and the French Defense, among others. The resulting pawn structures may also be asymmetrical, as in the [[Caro-Kann Defence|Caro-Kann Defense]] and Queen's Gambit Declined. In the [[Ruy Lopez, Exchange Variation]] pieces (White's bishop and Black's knight) rather than pawns are traded. In the Exchange Variation of the [[Grunfeld Defence|Grunfeld Defense]], both a pair of pawns and a pair of knights are traded.
The diagram at right shows a position in the Exchange Variation of the French Defense, after the moves: :'''1. e4 e6''' :'''2. d4 d5''' :'''3. exd5 exd5'''
The position is completely symmetrical and White's advantage is limited to his right to move. The Exchange French is usually regarded as a passive alternative selected by a White player eager for a draw, but [[Paul Morphy]] and more recently [[Garry Kasparov]] have used it as a winning try.
==Openings with exchange variations== * [[Caro-Kann Defence|Caro-Kann Defense]] (1.e4 c6 2.d4 d5 3.exd5 cxd5) * [[French Defence|French Defense]] (1.e4 e6 2.d4 d5 3.exd5 exd5) * [[Grünfeld Defence|Grünfeld Defense]] (1.d4 Nf6 2.c4 g6 3.Nc3 d5 4.cxd5 Nxd5 5.e4 Nxc3 6.bxc3) * [[Queen's Gambit Declined]] (1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 3.cxd5 exd5; often White delays the exchange for one or more moves) * [[Ruy Lopez, Exchange Variation]] (1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bb5 a6 4.Bxc6; deferred exchange variations are also known, such as 4.Ba4 Nf6 5.0-0 Be7 6.Bxc6, the so-called Delayed Exchange Ruy Lopez Deferred (DERLD)) * [[Slav Defense]] (1.d4 d5 2.c4 c6 3.cxd5 cxd5) * [[Alekhine Defense]] (1.e4 Nf6 2.e5 Nd5 3.d4 d6 4.c4 Nb6 5.exd6)
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Chess openings|*Exchange variation]] [[Category:Chess terminology]]

{{Infobox sport | name =Fleet racing | image =Fleet Racing Mumbai.jpg | imagesize =250px | caption =The start of a fleet race | union =[[World Sailing]] | nickname = | first = | registered = | clubs = | contact =No | team = | mgender = | category =Outdoor, Aquatic | equipment = | venue = | obsolete = | olympic = | paralympic = }} '''Fleet racing''' is a form of competitive [[Sailing (sport)|sailing]] that involves [[sailboat]]s racing one another over a set course. It is the most common form of sailboat racing and contrasts with [[match race|match racing]] and [[team racing]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Sailing For Dummies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ukOmqlx7u-QC&pg=PA269&dq=fleet+racing&hl=en&ei=yHgfTemXFIPfceehsAM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=fleet%20racing&f=false|year=2006|publisher=For Dummies|isbn=0-471-79143-1|page=269}}</ref>
Fleet racing can take place in two main formats. In the [[one-design|"One-Design"]] basis, all boats in the fleet are of the same class (i.e., the same design, length, and sail area). Alternatively, different classes of boats can race on a [[Handicapping|handicap]] basis, where faster classes give time to slower classes either by starting the race later or having their finishing times adjusted after the race's completion.<ref>{{cite book|title=Sailing For Dummies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ukOmqlx7u-QC&pg=PA269&dq=fleet+racing&hl=en&ei=yHgfTemXFIPfceehsAM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=fleet%20racing&f=false|year=2006|publisher=For Dummies|isbn=0-471-79143-1|page=270}}</ref> Racing can occur around or between [[buoy]]s or geographical features such as islands, and take place over short inshore courses or long distances offshore (such as the [[Volvo Ocean Race]]).
The [[Racing Rules of Sailing|rules for fleet racing]] are set by [[World Sailing]] and can be supplemented by race-specific rules set by the organisers of a particular race.<ref name="Robinson310"/> Contraventions of the rules are resolved either by a boat voluntarily taking a penalty during the race, or by protest lodged and heard after the race. The rules of match racing, on the other hand, are normally enforced by umpires issuing penalties during a race.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://slsailing.com/2010/06/%E2%80%9Cmatch-racing%E2%80%9D-%E2%80%93-part-ii-what-is-match-racing/|title=“Match Racing” – Part II: What is Match Racing?|last=Woodget|first=Bea|date=11 June 2010|work=SL Sailing|accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref>
Fleet racing involves fewer strategic and tactical considerations for the sailor than match racing.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Smith|first1=Lissa|last2=Nelson|first2=Maria Burton|title=Nike Is a Goddess: The History of Women in Sports|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SOwKTgEnTBsC&pg=PA124&dq=fleet+racing+match+racing&hl=en&ei=N3sfTfCFK8jCcfjm7NcK&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=fleet%20racing%20match%20racing&f=false|year=1999|publisher=Atlantic Monthly Press|isbn=0-87113-761-5|page=124}}</ref> In fleet racing, the most important factor in the outcome of a race is usually the speed of each boat.<ref name="Robinson310"/> Three-time Olympic sailing gold medallist [[Ben Ainslie]], who made a foray into match racing for the [[2007 America's Cup]], has described the differences between fleet racing and match racing as "huge".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/4561893.stm|title=Ainslie denies Cup role misery|date=19 May 2005|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref>
In the [[Sailing at the 2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Olympics]], all eleven sailing events were One-Design fleet races.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/olympics/2008/sports/sailing/format.htm|title=Sailing|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=1 January 2011}}</ref> On the other hand, the [[America's Cup]] is sailed as a series of match races.<ref name="Robinson310">{{cite book|last1=Robinson|first1=Robby|last2=Robinson|first2=William H.|title=The International Marine Book of Sailing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=42xo5JrS-YUC&pg=PA310&dq=fleet+racing+match+racing&hl=en&ei=N3sfTfCFK8jCcfjm7NcK&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=fleet%20racing%20match%20racing&f=false|year=2008|publisher=McGraw-Hill Professional|isbn=0-07-053225-7|page=310}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=February 2010}}
'''Grandmaster''' (or '''Grand Master''') and '''Master''' are titles used to describe or address some senior or experienced [[martial arts|martial artists]]. Typically these titles are honorary in nature, meaning that they do not confer rank, but rather distinguish the individual as very highly revered in their school, system, or style.
== History == Asian martial arts traditionally use terms that are usually translated as "[[teacher]]"<ref name="aznhealth"/> and the use of "[[Wikt:Master|master]]" was a [[Western culture|Western]] invention derived from 1950s [[United States]] war veterans returning home<ref name="aznhealth"/>{{clarify|date=October 2014}}<!--whoever wrote this does not seem to be aware that 'master' is a perfectly mundane title given to anyone authorised to teach any craft, nothing 'exalted' about the term itself.--> with stories of the incredible martial feats of certain individuals and groups. Subsequently, they found their way into martial arts culture as marketing tactics to the extent that the titles are aligned to the 'elderly martial arts master' stock character. In Asian countries, such titles are more commonly reserved for religious leaders and saints.<ref name="aznhealth"/>
== Modern use == The use of "master," "grandmaster," etc. is decided within an individual art or organization. The use may be self assigned; for example having promoted a student to 'teacher' level, or may be assigned by a governing body in arts with a more formalised structure, and some do not use it at all, for historic reasons or to avoid the 'elderly master' stereotype. The modern use of [[Dan (rank)|''Dan'']] rankings and [[Black belt (martial arts)|Black belt]] and [[Red belt (martial arts)|Red belt]] in martial arts both derive from [[Judo]] where they were adopted by its founder [[Kanō Jigorō]].<ref name=Ranks>[http://www.judoinfo.com/ranks.htm Ranking Systems in Modern Japanese Martial Arts: Modern vs. Classical] by [[Donn F. Draeger]], Lecture on 1 April 1976.</ref>
== Traditional systems == There are many terms similar or equivalent to 'grandmaster' used by various martial arts traditions. Some of these terms derive from older systems, while others are relatively modern.
=== Japan === [[Japanese martial arts]] commonly use '''''[[Sensei]]''''' (先生) meaning "teacher" or literally translated, "born first"<ref name="aznhealth" /> or "one who has gone before".<ref name="judoinfo">[http://www.judoinfo.com/sensei1.htm What is a Sensei?] Neil Ohlenkamp, judoinfo.com</ref> A ''Sensei'' is a person who has knowledge and is willing to teach that knowledge to another. A ''Sensei'' assists students in ''ken shiki'' "the pursuit of knowledge".<ref name="judoinfo" /> Some organizations, such as the [[Bujinkan]], [[Kodokan]] (Judo), and [[Shodokan Aikido]], use the term '''''[[shihan]]''''' for high-ranking or highly distinguished instructors. {{Nihongo|'''''[[Sōke]]'''''|宗家}}, meaning "the head family [house],"<ref>Kenkyusha's New Japanese-English Dictionary</ref> is sometimes used to refer to "founder of a style" because many modern sōke are the first generation headmasters of their art, but most correctly refers to the current head. A sōke is considered the ultimate authority within their art and has the authority to issue a ''[[menkyo kaiden]]'' certificate indicating that someone has mastered all aspects of the style.<ref>[http://www.koryubooks.com/library/wbodiford1.html#b1 Soke: Historical Incarnations of a Title and its Entitlements by William M. Bodiford ]</ref>
=== Korea === The actual Korean word for a student's master is '''''sonsaeng'''''. This term is only used by the student when speaking to the instructor. The student is ''hakseang''.<ref name="MAFCI">[http://www.mafci.com/terminology/ Korean Terminology] Martial Arts Fitness Centers, Inc.</ref> (학생 HakSaeng 學生) Many Korean titles are often mistakenly translated as "grandmaster" (태사님 TaeSaNim 太師님). '''''Sonseang-nim''''' (선생님 SeonSaengNim 先生님) is a general term for a teacher of any subject as well as a respectful form of the word "you". Martial arts instructors (in Korea 4th Dan and above) are called ''Sabom-nim'' (사범님 SaBeomNim 師範님).
=== China === Various dialects of the [[Chinese language]] use different terms.
"Sifu" is a common romanization, although the term and pronunciation are also used in other southern languages. In [[Mandarin Chinese]], it is spelled "shifu" in [[pinyin]]. Using [[Rhotic and non-rhotic accents|non-rhotic]] British English pronunciation, in Mandarin it would sound something similar to "sure foo". Using [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]], 'shi' is pronounced 'ʂɨ'. The 'i' is a short vowel. Many martial arts studios incorrectly pronounce this like "she foo". In Cantonese, it is said as "see foo" (almost like "sea food", without the "d" on the end). (師傅 or 師父; [[Pinyin]]: ''shīfu'', Standard pinyin: ''si1 fu6'') a modern term for "teacher".
The term ''Shifu'' is a combination of the characters "teacher" and "father" (師父) or a combination of the characters "teacher" and "mentor" (師傅). The traditional Chinese martial arts school, or ''[[kwoon]]'' (館, guǎn) is an extended family headed by the Shifu. The Shifu's teacher is the "師公 honorable master" or ''Shigong''. Similarly the Shifu's wife is the ''Shimu'' "teacher mother" and the grandmaster's wife is known as: 師姥 shi lao; or 師婆 shi po. Male and female students who began training before you and are thus senior, are 師兄''Shixiong'' "teacher older brothers" and 師姐 ''Shijie'' "teacher's sisters". Women in traditional society did not have the same status as males (despite what modern movies depict). Students junior to you are your ''Shidi'' and ''Shimei''. The pattern extends to uncles, aunts, cousins, great uncles, and so forth (see above for a complete list of relational terms).<ref name="aznhealth" />
== Popular culture == Such titles may be, to some extent, aligned to the ''[[elderly martial arts master]]'' stock character in fiction. In [[Oriental]] martial arts, traditional titular systems vary between nations and arts, but terms such as "[[teacher]]"<ref name="aznhealth">[http://www.aznhealth.com/column2/master.html Master vs. Sifu in Chinese Martial Arts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061018090141/http://www.aznhealth.com/column2/master.html |date=2006-10-18 }} Traditional Asian Health Center</ref> were more common than "master." The modern use came from Eastern to Western society in the 1950s with stories of martial feats seen in [[Asia]].

'''1st:''' €150,000 }} The '''Grosser Preis von Baden''' is a [[Group races|Group 1]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in Germany open to [[thoroughbred]]s aged three years or older. It is run at [[Baden-Baden]] over a distance of 2,400 metres (about 1½ miles), and it is scheduled to take place each year in early September. ==History== The event was established in 1858, and it was originally contested over 3,200 metres. The inaugural running was part of a three-day festival which celebrated the opening of Baden-Baden's Iffezheim Racecourse. The race was shortened to 2,800 metres in 1887. It was titled the Jubiläums-Preis on several occasions during the 1890s. Its distance was cut to 2,200 metres in 1894, and extended to 2,400 metres in 1898. The Grosser Preis von Baden was staged at [[Hoppegarten]] from 1942 to 1944. It was not contested from 1945 to 1947, and it was known as the Grosser Preis von Iffezheim in 1948 and 1949. The present system of race grading was introduced in Germany in 1972, and the Grosser Preis von Baden was classed at Group 1 level. It was run in two separate divisions in 1974. The race has had several different sponsors since the mid-1990s, and these have included [[Mercedes-Benz]], [[Volkswagen]] and [[Longines]]. The Grosser Preis von Baden was added to the [[Breeders' Cup Challenge]] series in 2012. The winner earned an automatic invitation to compete in the same year's [[Breeders' Cup Turf]].{{cite web | title = 2012 Breeders' Cup Challenge Schedule | url = https://members.breederscup.com/doc%20repository/other/ChallengeSchedule.pdf | publisher = breederscup.com | accessdate = 29 April 2012}} The race was removed from the series after the 2017 running. ==Records== '''Most successful horse (3 wins):''' * [[Kincsem]] – ''1877, 1878, 1879'' * Oleander – ''1927, 1928, 1929'' ---- '''Leading [[jockey]] (5 wins):''' * Gerhard Streit – ''Magnat (1941), Samurai (1943), Mangon (1952), Baal (1954), Masetto (1956)'' ---- '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (7 wins):''' * George Arnull – ''Oleander (1927, 1928, 1929), Alba (1930), Widerhall (1932), Magnat (1941), Samurai (1943)'' : ''(note: the trainers of some of the early winners are unknown)'' ---- '''Leading owner (10 wins):''' * Gestüt Schlenderhan – ''Gastgeber (1875), Oleander (1927, 1928, 1929), Alba (1930), Widerhall (1932), Magnat (1941), Samurai (1943), Alpenkönig (1970), Ivanhowe (2014)'' {{clear}} ==Winners since 1968== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! revision.text:
'''Hiking apparel''' is [[clothing]], footwear, headwear, and other items worn that are suitable for [[hiking]], including [[trousers]], [[sweater]]s, [[underwear]], and [[hiking boot]]s. Hiking apparel is usually selected to suit predicted [[weather]] conditions, taking into account [[Ultraviolet protection factor|UPF]] rating (Ultraviolet Protection Factor), weight, water and wind resistance. Today's hiking apparel is more advanced than previous years, having material that can be wind resistant, [[Waterproofing#In clothing|water-repellent]] and yet breathable, and lightweight. Some hiking apparel is designed to be "breathable", drawing moisture away from the body while protecting from the weather.
Usually three layers of apparel are worn on a rough-weather hike, the first being mostly of synthetic material drawing moisture from the body, the second being of material with high thermal insulation capacity, and the third being of wind- and water-resistant material.<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=COWYE6LxZHwC&pg=PA202|year=2000|title=The complete idiot's guide to camping and hiking|isbn=978-0-02-863186-8|author=Michael Moulan|chapter=ch. 16 - Ways to Dress for Success in the Outdoors}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://hikingapparelguide.com/|title=Hiking Apparel Guide}}</ref>
Today's hiking boots have been designed to give maximum [[ankle]] support, and to be durable but light in weight. Many have a long-lasting hardened rubber [[Sole (shoe)|sole]].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Hiking apparel| ]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=August 2014}}
'''Infield''' is a sports term whose definition depends on the sport in whose context it is used.
== Baseball ==
In [[baseball]] the [[baseball diamond]] plus a region beyond it, has both grass and dirt, in contrast to the more distant, usually grass-covered ''outfield''. It also refers to the defensive unit of players that are positioned in the region: [[first baseman]], [[second baseman]], [[shortstop]], [[third baseman]]. Sometimes it includes the [[catcher]] and [[pitcher]] who (as a tandem) are often referred to separately as the [[Battery (baseball)|battery]].
In baseball the physical infield is where most of the action in a baseball game occurs, as it includes that area where the all-important duel between the [[pitcher]] and [[batting (baseball)|batter]] takes place.<ref>Baseball Explained by Phillip Mahony, McFarland Books, 2014. See [http://www.baseballexplained.com www.baseballexplained.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813034018/http://www.baseballexplained.com/ |date=2014-08-13 }}</ref> The pitcher stands on the [[pitcher's mound]] (a raised mound of dirt located at the center of the infield) and from there he pitches the ball to his [[catcher]], who is crouched behind home plate sixty feet, six inches away at what might be called the cutlet of the diamond-shaped baseball field. To the left and right of the catcher are chalk boxes in the dirt called [[Baseball_field#Batter.27s_box_and_catcher.27s_box|batter's boxes]]. The opposing team's batter must stand in one of the two boxes and from there he will attempt to hit the pitched ball with his bat. The [[umpire]], who officiates the game, stands behind the catcher. The other important parts of the infield are the three [[base (baseball)|bases]], [[first base]] (to the pitcher's left, looking toward home plate), [[second base]] (behind the pitcher) and [[third base]] (to the pitcher's right). Together, home plate and the three bases form a diamond around the pitcher, with each side of the diamond measuring 90 feet.<ref>Baseball Explained by Phillip Mahony, McFarland Books, 2014. See [http://www.baseballexplained.com www.baseballexplained.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813034018/http://www.baseballexplained.com/ |date=2014-08-13 }}</ref>
== Cricket ==
In [[cricket]] infield is a central oval on the [[cricket field]], the reference point for fielding restrictions in short forms of the game; in contrast to the more distant ''outfield''
==Tracks== Infield can refer to a region inside a closed [[horse racing]] or [[auto racing]] track, or to an area encircled by the track of a [[roller coaster]].
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Baseball}}
[[Category:Baseball field]] [[Category:Terminology used in multiple sports]]

[[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]] | coordinates = {{Coord|64|08|36.9|N|21|52|44.2|W|display=inline,title|type:landmark_region:IS}} | broke_ground =1949 | built = | opened =17 June 1959 | renovated =1970, 1997 and 2007 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 15,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Iceland national football team|Iceland men's national football team]]
[[Iceland women's national football team]]
[[Iceland national under-21 football team|Iceland U21]]
[[Iceland national under-19 football team|Iceland U19]]
[[Knattspyrnufélagið Fram]] (temporary) | website = | publictransit = | former_names = | construction_cost = }} '''Laugardalsvöllur''' ({{IPA-is|ˈløiːɣar.talsˌvœtl̥ʏr̥}}) is [[Iceland]]'s [[national stadium|national football stadium]] and the home venue for the [[Iceland national football team]]. It is in [[Reykjavík]] and seats 9,800 with a total capacity of 15,000. ==History== The idea of building a sport venue in Laugardalur, along with some other entertainment facilities, dates back to 1871. At that time, the population of Reykjavík, the capital of Iceland, was only about 2,000. Laugardalur was also nearly 3 km (1.9 mi) away from residential areas. Little came out of this proposal the next 60 years or so. In 1943, the town council set up the Laugardalsnefnd committee. Its task was to make proposals and ideas for the area. The committee then delivered the result later, which included building a new football stadium and a [[Laugardalslaug|new swimming pool]]. Construction of the field started in 1949 and lasted until 1952. A year later in 1953, construction of a new stand started. The stand had a capacity of 4,000 when completed. The first match was played on Laugardalsvöllur in 1957 when the [[Iceland national football team|Iceland men's national football team]] played against [[Norway national football team|Norway]], two years before the official opening on 17 June 1959. A few years later, the stand was renovated and expanded, starting from 1965 to 1970.{{Cite web|url=http://2012.skjaladagur.is/?p=488|title=Íþróttaleikvangur Reykjavíkur í LaugardalSaga framkvæmdanna|date=6 November 2012|language=is-IS|access-date=2016-09-26}} Under the new stand there was opened a [[Track and field|track-and-field]] facility, which operated until 2007, although there has always been [[all-weather running track]] around the pitch (upgraded in 1992). Later the year 1992, floodlights were inaugurated for the match against [[Greece national football team|Greece]]. In 1997, another new stand was built against the old stand, across the pitch. Constructions started a year earlier. It has a capacity of 3,500. At the same time, the old stand was relieved by matching it with the new stand by seating capacity.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mbl.is/greinasafn/grein/343832/|title=Ártöl í sögu knattspyrnunnar á Íslandi 1892 "Knattleikur er t.d. flestra unglinga yndi og mætti tíðka hann miklu meira en gert|website=www.mbl.is|access-date=2016-09-26}} Big renovation and expansion of the old stand started in 2005. After the completion in 2007, the stadium has a capacity of 9,800. Additional capacity can be added by bringing in two temporary stands seating 1,500 each, giving the stadium a [[maximum]] capacity of 15,000 but after the new requirements of [[FIFA]] for national football stadiums, this addition method has been forbidden. No major renovations or expansions have occurred since 2007.{{Cite journal|last=Rúnarsson|first=Kristján Jens|date=1 January 2016|title=Stækkun Laugardalsvallar : Er skynsamlegt fyrir Reykjavíkurborg að taka þátt í hugsanlegum breytingum?|url=http://hdl.handle.net/1946/25150}} The largest attendance for a football match ever seen by Laugardalsvöllur was 20,204 in 2004 in a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] between Iceland and [[Italy national football team|Italy]]. The largest attendance for the venue about 25,000 during a concert in 2007.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ksi.is/mannvirki/laugardagsvollur/|title=Þjóðarleikvangur Íslands {{!}} Knattspyrnusamband Íslands|website=www.ksi.is|access-date=2016-09-26}} On 24 July 2018, American rock band [[Guns N' Roses]] played at the stadium in font of 25,000 people, at that time the largest rock concert ever held in Iceland. http://icelandmag.is/article/interview-axl-rose-guns-nroses-reykjavik-concert-largest-icelandic-history == Facilities == The stadium comprises two big stands facing each other. West Stand is the main stand and the larger one. It is the only stand to hold all the facilities needed for the stadium, excluding [[stadium seating]]. For the purpose of football matches and other competitions, the stand has 4 changing rooms for players (mainly) and 2 others for [[referee]]s, which also have the capability of accommodating facility for a doctor or [[drug test]]. There are two other rooms for football matches and [[Sport of athletics|athletics tournaments]] administration. == Future == There have been plans to renovate and expand Laugardalsvöllur since [[Iceland national football team|Iceland men's national football team]] reached play-off for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in 2013. The team's success kept going until they went to [[UEFA Euro 2016]] and reached [[quarter-finals]]. Both Icelandic football fans and [[Football Association of Iceland|KSÍ (the Football Association of Iceland)]] have been asking for new stadium because seats have sold out for nearly all official matches (even friendly matches) since 2013. Several ways are available, but all of them have at least two things in common: removing the running track and cover the stadium. KSÍ has stated that it wants a [[Retractable roof stadium|retractable-roof stadium]] for the possibility of [[multi-purpose stadium]], that would increase the utilization of seating capacity in the long term. There are stadiums in Europe that can be used as a guide for Iceland. They are all big and extremely expensive on the local scale. The upcoming construction of Laugardalsvöllur is, for instance, expected to cost about 8 billion [[Icelandic króna|ISK]] (about €62 million). If built, the new national football stadium of Iceland is likely to have a capacity of 20,000 or more. The pitch itself would have to be dug many meters in the ground since the running track is to be removed and the bottom edge of the stadium will be moved closer to the pitch. By doing that, the stadium will have a lot more capacity. The new pitch is expected to be heated if natural grass is selected, due to hard winters in Iceland and also because of the new requirements of [[UEFA]], which indicates that matches for some teams in the [[UEFA European Championship qualifying|qualification competition]], for the [[UEFA European Championship]], shall also be played in the winter.{{Cite news|url=http://www.ruv.is/frett/hotel-og-haskoli-a-nyjum-laugardalsvelli|title=Hótel og háskóli á nýjum Laugardalsvelli?|date=26 September 2016|newspaper=RÚV|access-date=2016-10-07}} The grass would then be maintained itself with an [[Irrigation|automatic irrigation sprinkler system]]. Because the new stadium requires a retractable roof to cover the costs, it is possible that all present structures of Laugardalsvöllur will be demolished and a new, solid, oval-shaped stadium will be built; neither of the existing stands are specially designed to support additional roof that can roll back and forth on tracks, that can open and close the stadium altogether. ==Gallery== File:Laugardalsvöllur.jpg|Laugardalsvöllur during a [[UEFA Euro 2008 qualifying|Euro 2008 qualifying]] game File:IcelandvsSlovakia.jpg|Laugardalsvöllur during the friendly match [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]]-[[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]], in 2009 File:Laugardalsvollur from south west.JPG|The arena seen from the footpath along Reykjavegur ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.ksi.is/mannvirki/laugardagsvollur/ Official website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080327090315/http://www.ksi.is/english Football Association of Iceland] {{DEFAULTSORT:Laugardalsvollur}} [[Category:Football venues in Iceland]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Iceland]] [[Category:National stadiums|Iceland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Reykjavík]] [[Category:Knattspyrnufélagið Fram]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1959]] [[Category:1959 establishments in Iceland]]

revision.text:
[[File:Michael_Schumacher-I'm_the_man_(cropped).jpg|right|thumb|upright|Schumacher in 2005]] [[Michael Schumacher]] is a German racing driver who won seven [[Formula One]] [[List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions|world championships]]. Schumacher entered Formula One with the [[Jordan Grand Prix|Jordan]] racing team in 1991, qualifying seventh in his debut race at the [[Belgian Grand Prix]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/f1/motorsport/story/56964.html|last=Hay-Nicholls|first=Adam|title=It was 20 years ago...|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=23 August 2011|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=HoF/> Following this race, he was signed by [[Benetton Formula|Benetton]] for the rest of the season.<ref name=HoF>{{cite web|url=http://www.formula1.com/content/fom-website/en/championship/drivers/hall-of-fame/Michael_Schumacher.html|title=Michael Schumacher|publisher=[[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]]|accessdate=26 May 2016}}</ref> His first Grand Prix win came the following year at the same venue as his debut race. Schumacher won his first Formula One World Championship in 1994, a season in which he won eight races. His victory was controversial, as he was involved in a collision with fellow championship contender [[Damon Hill]] at the final race in [[Adelaide Street Circuit|Adelaide]]. Both drivers had to retire their cars which resulted in Schumacher securing the championship.<ref name=HoF/><ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/michael-schumacher/7718722/Michael-Schumachers-top-five-F1-controversies.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | title = Michael Schumacher's top five F1 controversies | date = 13 May 2010 | first = Giles | last = Mole | accessdate = 26 May 2016}}</ref> He won his second championship the following year, winning nine races, and became the youngest double world champion at the time.<ref name=sky/>{{efn|[[Fernando Alonso]] broke this record in 2006, and he has since been surpassed by [[Sebastian Vettel]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/motorsport/alonso-tipped-to-equal-schumachers-success/2006/10/22/1161455610695.html|title=Alonso tipped to equal Schumacher's success|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=23 October 2006|accessdate=1 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/formula1/15241395|title=Sebastian Vettel 'unlikely' to break Schumacher record|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=10 October 2011|accessdate=1 June 2016|last=Benson|first=Andrew}}</ref>}}
Schumacher joined [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] in 1996. He finished third in the championship, winning three races, in a season dominated by the [[Williams Grand Prix Engineering|Williams]] team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grandprix.com/ft/ft00244.html|title=Review of the year 1996|last=Saward|first=Joe|date=2 December 1996|accessdate=29 May 2016|publisher=Inside F1|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409175501/http://www.grandprix.com/ft/ft00244.html|archivedate=9 April 2016|df=}}</ref> His victory at the [[1996 Spanish Grand Prix|Spanish Grand Prix]], which Schumacher won by 45 seconds, is noted as one of the great Formula One wet weather drives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/formula1/36277172|title=Spanish Grand Prix: Why Michael Schumacher's epic 1996 win matters|publisher=BBC|date=14 May 2016|accessdate=26 May 2016|last=Benson|first=Andrew}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://en.espn.co.uk/f1/motorsport/story/26366.html| publisher = ESPN | accessdate = 26 May 2016 | title = Winning in the rain | first =Fraser | last= Masefield | date = 24 August 2010}}</ref> In the 1997 season, Schumacher won five races but was disqualified from the championship after the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]] concluded that he had deliberately collided with [[Jacques Villeneuve]], his championship rival, at the [[1997 European Grand Prix|European Grand Prix]] in [[Circuito Permanente de Jerez|Jerez]].<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/29895.stm | title = Schumacher loses championship runner-up crown | date = 11 November 1997 | accessdate = 26 May 2016 | publisher = BBC News}}</ref> The following year, he won six races. Schumacher won his third world championship in 2000; the first for a Ferrari driver since 1979.<ref name=ferrari>{{cite web | url = http://en.espn.co.uk/f1/motorsport/page/3399.html | title =A History of Ferrari | accessdate = 26 May 2016 | publisher = ESPN}}</ref> He followed this with four consecutive championships from 2001 to 2004. During the 2001 season, at the [[2001 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]], Schumacher won his 52nd Grand Prix, breaking [[Alain Prost]]'s record for the most career Grand Prix wins.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/3011989/Belgian-Grand-Prix-Schumacher-breaks-Prosts-record-in-bizarre-afternoon-of-racing.html|title=Belgian Grand Prix: Schumacher breaks Prost's record in bizarre afternoon of racing|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=2 September 2001|accessdate=2 June 2016|last=Mossop|first=James}}</ref> His 2002 season, in which he was on the podium in every race, included eleven race victories. The latter broke the record for the most wins in a single season.<ref name=sky>{{Cite web | url = http://www.skysports.com/f1/news/12430/10101867/michael-schumachers-best-f1-moment | title = Michael Schumacher best moments: How F1's records were rewritten |publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|first = James | last = Galloway | date = 30 December 2015 | accessdate = 26 May 2016}}</ref> Schumacher surpassed this with thirteen race victories in 2004.<ref name=sky/><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-12-30/michael-schumacher-the-greatest-formula-one-driver-of-all-time/5178660 | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | title = Michael Schumacher the greatest Formula One driver of all time, seven world titles and 91 race victories | date = 28 January 2014 | accessdate = 26 May 2016}}</ref>{{efn|[[Sebastian Vettel]] matched this record in 2013. Note that there was one more race in the 2013 season than in the 2004 season.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2013/nov/24/sebastian-vettel-f1-grand-prix-win-brazil|title=Sebastian Vettel achieves ninth straight F1 grand prix win in Brazil|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 November 2013|accessdate=2 June 2016|last=Weaver|first=Paul}}</ref>}} His final Grand Prix win was at the [[2006 Chinese Grand Prix]]; at the end of that season he retired from Formula One.<ref name=HoF/> Although he made a return to Formula One racing with [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] between 2010 and 2012, this did not result in any further victories.<ref name=ret2/>
Schumacher contested 308 races in his career which included 91 Grand Prix wins;<ref name=ret2>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/9692950/Brazil-Grand-Prix-2012-this-retirement-is-not-as-emotional-as-the-first-says-Michael-Schumacher.html|title=Brazil Grand Prix 2012: this retirement is not as emotional as the first, says Michael Schumacher|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=21 November 2012|accessdate=2 June 2016}}</ref> the majority of his race victories were for the Ferrari team with 72. His most successful circuit was [[Circuit de Nevers Magny-Cours|Magny-Cours]] where he won eight times in his career. Schumacher's largest margin of victory was at the [[1994 Brazilian Grand Prix]], a race in which he lapped the field, and the smallest margin of victory was at the [[2000 Canadian Grand Prix]] when he beat teammate [[Rubens Barrichello]] by 0.174 seconds.
==Wins==
[[File:Schumacher M accum of wins.svg|thumb|Michael Schumacher accumulated 91 Grand Prix victories through the first 16-year period of his career since entering Formula One.]]

[[Las Vegas Sands Corporation]] |operator=[[The Madison Square Garden Company]] |surface= |scoreboard= |production= |cost= |architect= Populous |project_manager= |structural engineer= |services engineer= |general_contractor= |main_contractors= |seating_type= |capacity=18,000 |suites= |record_attendance= |dimensions= |field_shape= |acreage= |volume= |tenants= |embedded= |website= |publictransit= [[Las Vegas Monorail]], Sands Expo Station
[[RTC Transit]]
[[The Deuce (transit bus service)|The Deuce]] }} The '''MSG Sphere Las Vegas''' is an under-construction music and entertainment venue being built in [[Paradise, Nevada]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/casinos-gaming/work-begins-on-18000-seat-msg-sphere-at-the-venetian/|title=Work begins on 18,000-seat MSG Sphere at The Venetian – Las Vegas Review-Journal|website=reviewjournal.com|accessdate=2018-10-19}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2018/02/14/populous-build-spherical-music-venue-las-vegas-usa-london-uk-msg-sphere-london|title=Populous to build spherical music venues in Vegas and London|date=2018-02-14|work=Dezeen|access-date=2018-10-10|language=en-US}} ==History== Construction on the venue began in 2018 and will be complete by 2021. The venue is being built in partnership between [[The Madison Square Garden Company]] and [[Las Vegas Sands Corporation]].{{Cite news|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2018/jul/19/lv-sands-commits-75-million-to-msg-sphere-arena-pr/|title=LV Sands commits $75 million to MSG Sphere arena project|date=2018-07-19|work=LasVegasSun.com|access-date=2018-08-09|language=en}} The MSG Sphere will be located adjacent to [[The Venetian Las Vegas]] and just off the [[Las Vegas Strip]]. Once complete, the sphere-shaped venue will have a capacity of 18,000 are will feature [[LED]] screens inside and outside of the venue. An [[MSG Sphere London|identical MSG Sphere]] will be built in [[London]] and will open sometime after the MSG Sphere in Las Vegas.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/all-you-need-to-know-about-the-planned-msg-sphere-london-a3897671.html|title=All you need to know about the planned MSG Sphere London|website=London Evening Standard|accessdate=2018-10-20}} In November 2018, it was reported that the MSG Sphere would be built along with new bars, private suites, a museum and retail space.[https://lasvegassun.com/news/2018/nov/01/msg-sphere-arena-project-calls-for-bars-museum-pri/ MSG Sphere project calls for bars, museum, private suites, new Monorail stop] ==Features== The MSG Sphere will be equipped with 19,000 by 13,500 resolution LED screens which will spread across the interior of the venue. All 18,000 seats will have high speed internet access. The sound system will deliver sound through the floorboards. The exterior of the venue will feature a 360 degree IMAX display which will allow those who are outside of the venue to see what is going on inside.[http://www.thembj.org/2018/11/the-msg-sphere-the-future-of-live-concert-experiences/ The MSG Sphere: The Future of Live Concert Experiences] ==Transit links== The MSG Sphere Las Vegas will be accessible via the [[Las Vegas Monorail]], [[RTC Transit]] and [[The Deuce (transit bus service)|The Deuce]]. ===New Monorail Station=== A new [[Las Vegas Monorail]] station has been proposed to serve the MSG Sphere and The Venetian.https://lasvegassun.com/news/2018/nov/01/msg-sphere-arena-project-calls-for-bars-museum-pri/ In November 2018, it was confirmed that the new monorail station would be built.[https://www.reviewjournal.com/business/monorail-station-planned-for-msg-sphere-arena-in-las-vegas-1532702/amp/ Monorail station planned for MSG Sphere arena in Las Vegas] ==See also== *[[MSG Sphere London]] *[[Ericsson Globe]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Las Vegas Strip}} {{Las Vegas Sands Corporation}} {{Music venues of Nevada}} {{Madison Square Garden Company}} {{coord|36|07|18|N|115|09|57|W|type:landmark_region:US-NV|display=title}} [[Category:Madison Square Garden Company]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Paradise, Nevada]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Music venues in the Las Vegas Valley]] [[Category:Sports venues in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Boxing venues in Las Vegas]] [[Category:Las Vegas Strip]] [[Category:Indoor arenas under construction in the United States]] {{sports-venue-stub}}

{{Motorsport venue | Name = Myrtle Beach Speedway | Time = GMT-5 | Location = {{nowrap|[[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]]}} | Coordinates = {{coord|33|44|47|N|78|57|7|W|region:US-SC_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | Image = MyrtleBeachSpeedway.svg | Image_Caption = | Capacity = 12,000 (Oval) | Owner = | Opened = 1958 | Former Names = Rambi Raceway (1958 - 1974) | Events = [[NASCAR Whelen Modified Tour]] | Layout1 = D-oval | Surface = Asphalt | Miles_first = 0.538 | Length_km = 0.866 | Length_mi = 0.538 | Banking = Turns - 13°
Straights - 4° front, 3° back }} The '''Myrtle Beach Speedway''', originally named Rambi Raceway, was built in 1958 and is located on [[U.S. Route 501]] near [[Myrtle Beach]], [[South Carolina]]. The speedway is a semi-banked [[asphalt]] oval track that spans {{convert|0.538|mi|km}}.The [[NASCAR]] Cup series competed at the Speedway from 1958 through 1965. The [[NASCAR]] Busch Series (now the [[Xfinity Series]]) raced at Myrtle Beach Speedway from 1988 to 2000. Currently the NASCAR Whelen All-American Series race on Saturday nights from late February through November. The track also runs various other classes of racing including Late Model Charger, Super Trucks and Mini Stocks. The speedway is home of the Myrtle Beach 400, IceBreaker 200, NASCAR Racing Experience, Monster Jam, NOPI Nationals and Horry County Fair with recent additions of Wheels of Destruction Thrill Show and the Myrtle Beach BikeFest{{cite web|title=Start Your Engines at Myrtle Beach Speedway|url=https://www.compasscove.com/news/start-your-engines-at-myrtle-beach-speedway/|publisher=Compass Cove|accessdate=April 18, 2018}}. Over the years, Myrtle Beach Speedway has been the training grounds for some of NASCAR’s biggest stars including [[Dale Earnhardt Jr.]] (former late model stock car competitor) and [[Jeff Gordon]] (former Busch Series track record holder). All four generations of Pettys (Lee, Richard, Kyle, and Adam) and three generations of Earnhardts (Ralph, Dale Sr., and Dale Jr./[[Kelley Earnhardt Miller|Kelley]]/L.W. Miller III{{cite web|last=Newton|first=David|title=Junior took a backseat to big sis Kelley|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/cup/columns/story?id=4859211|publisher=[[ESPN]]|accessdate=March 21, 2014}}) have taken a green flag around the asphalt oval that spans {{convert|0.538|mi|km}}. ==History== [[File:NASCAR Racing Experience 24.jpg|thumb|right|A Late Model car belonging to The NASCAR Racing Experience]] Rambi Raceway opened as a dirt track in 1958. Nick Lucas bought the track in 1968, paving it in 1974. Billy Hardee became a co-owner in 1987. A [[Nationwide Series|Busch Series]] race (the [[Myrtle Beach 250]]) in 2000 was the last major [[NASCAR]] event at the track. By 2011, the [[Whelen All-American Series|NASCAR All-American Whelen Late-Model Series]] was the highest level of racing at the track. In a deal that closed April, 2012, Speedway Group Inc. bought the facility, including 48 acres. Robert J. Lutz, one of the new owners, said [[Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina|Lt. Gov.]] [[André Bauer]] arranged for the deal to take place. Bauer said he wanted the track to help improve Myrtle Beach's economy with new events. Upgrades to the track are planned, and plans call for the [[NASCAR Racing Experience]] to attract drivers and tourists. One goal is another top-level race.{{cite news|url=http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/2012/02/25/2679961/new-owners-have-big-plans-for.html|title=New owners have big plans for Myrtle Beach Speedway|last=Kanpek|first=Kurt|work=[[The Sun News]]|date=2012-02-25|accessdate=2012-02-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228205440/http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/2012/02/25/2679961/new-owners-have-big-plans-for.html|archivedate=2012-02-28|df=}} After merging the two NASCAR [[Whelen Modified Tour]]s at the end of the 2016 season, beginning in 2017, the newly unified tour started its season in Myrtle Beach. The track will again host the season opener in 2018. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.myrtlebeachspeedway.com/ Official Website] * [http://racing-reference.info/tracks/Myrtle_Beach_Speedway Race Results] * [https://www.iracing.com/tracks/myrtle-beach-speedway/ Track included in iRacing] {{Myrtle Beach}} {{NASCAR Whelen Modified Tour racetracks}} {{NASCAR Nationwide Series racetracks}} {{CARS Tour racetracks}} {{PASS Super Late Model Series racetracks}} {{CARS Pro Cup racetracks}} {{ISCARS Dash racetracks}} [[Category:Sports venues in Horry County, South Carolina]] [[Category:Motorsport venues in South Carolina]] [[Category:NASCAR tracks]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]] [[Category:Sports in Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]] [[Category:1958 establishments in South Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1958]] {{Autoracing-venue-stub}} {{SouthCarolina-stadium-stub}}

{{multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=March 2014}} {{Orphan|date=February 2014}} }}
'''Pan Pong''' (also '''Panpon''', '''Pan-Pon''' or '''Pang-Pong''') is a hybrid of [[tennis]] and [[ping pong]]. The name comes from the sound when the ball is being hit from one side to the next, pan - pon - pan - pon and is played on asphalt with racquets made of wood, a soft [[tennis ball]] and a net in form a wooden plank. Rules are similar to tennis or ping-pong but is played in shorter matches of 3 games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.film.hitachi.jp/movie/movie712.html |script-title=ja:パンポン−日立発祥の市民スポーツ− |website=HitachiTheatre |publisher=Hitachi, Ltd. |accessdate=17 February 2014|language=ja}}</ref>
== History ==
The game was invented in 1922, during the [[Taisho]] era (1912-1926), on the [[Hitachi]] Ltd. factory campus in Japan. Pan-Pon was started as a lunch exercise but has grown into a local sport in [[Ibaraki Prefecture]]. Tournaments within Hitachi plants, between plants, and among citizens in Ibaraki prefecture in Japan are organized. Outside Japan the sport is little known, but tournaments have been organized in [[Harrodsburg, Kentucky]], [[United States]], connected to the Hitachi Automotive plant there.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.centralkynews.com/2004-09-20/news/24876875_1_hitachi-city-pong-courts |title=Mercer adds pang pong at the park |last=Curd |first=Bobbie |date=20 September 2004 |website=Central Kentucky News |accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
== Rules ==
=== Court ===
Pan-pon is played on a rectangular flat court, normally outdoors on asphalt alternatively indoors on plastic floor. The court is 7 x 2.5 m with an inner serve area of 5.5 x 1 meter. The net is made of a 3-meter wooden plank, placed 40 cm above ground.
=== Equipment ===
Pans from the kitchen are made of wood, 30 x 20 cm and ca 10 mm in thickness. A simple ledge can be mounted on one of the short sides to make it easier to hold.
The ball is an air-pumped rubber ball, size like a tennis ball (ca 70 mm diameter). If the ball is dropped from 1 meter altitude it should bounce back up 50–60 cm if it is correctly pumped.
=== The game ===
Before the match a coin is flipped to determine the first server. One of the players will serve to start the game and the serve is hit into the receivers inner serve area without touching the net/plank. The receiver will hit the ball back into the servers court side.
=== Scoring ===
A game consists of a sequence of points played with the same player serving. The game is won by the first player to have won at least four points in total. If the score is 3-3 it is necessary to win with two points. At 4-4 it is enough to win with one point.
=== Serve ===
The serve is alternated between the players, point by point. The server must stand behind the base line and between the side lines. The receiver can stand at any place in the court. It is not allowed to hit the serve with the racket above the waist. The server only has one attempt to make a successful serve. The receiver is not allowed to hit the ball before it has touched the ground.
=== Doubles ===
If team A meets team B, first player A1 will serve with B1 as receiver. In the following game B1 serves to A2, then A2 against B2, etc.
== Nordic Pan-Pon Championships 2014 ==
In connection with the [[Nordic Microscopy Society|Nordic Microscopy]] Meeting, Scandem 2014, in [[Linköping, Sweden]], on June 9–13, 2014, the first Nordic championship in Pan-Pon will be held.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scandem2014.se/ |title=Scandem 2014 |accessdate=17 February 2014}}</ref>
