{{about|the ski resort in Utah|the mountain in British Columbia, Canada|Powder Mountain (British Columbia)|its associated icefield|Powder Mountain Icefield}} {{Advert|date=October 2014}} {{refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox ski area |name= Powder Mountain |logo= |picture= |caption= Powder Country |location= [[Cache County, Utah|Cache]] / [[Weber County, Utah|Weber]] counties, [[Utah]], [[United States|USA]] |nearest_city= [[Eden, Utah]] 7 miles (11 km) south, [[Ogden, Utah]] 19 miles (31 km) southwest, [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] 55 miles (89 km) south |coordinates = {{coord|41|22|48|N|111|46|49|W|type:landmark_scale:50000|display=inline}} |vertical= 2,205 ft (672 m) lift-served -- 2,522 ft (769 m) via snowcat |top_elevation= 8,900 ft (2,713 m) lift-served -- 9,422 ft (2872 m) via snowcat |base_elevation= 6,900 ft (2,103 m) |skiable_area= 2,800 acres (11.33 km²) lift-served -- 8,464 acres skiable area | number_trails = 167
[[Image:Ski trail rating symbol-green circle.svg|13px]] 25% beginner
[[Image:Ski trail rating symbol-blue square.svg|13px]] 40% intermediate
[[Image:Ski trail rating symbol-black diamond.svg|13px]] 30% advanced |longest_run= 3 mi (4.8 km) |liftsystem= 6 [[chairlift|chairs]], 3 [[surface lift]]s |lift_capacity= 6,350 skiers/hr |terrainparks= 2 |snowfall= 350 in./year (8.9 m/year) |snowmaking= none |nightskiing= 1 [[chairlift|chair]], 1 [[surface lift]], 7 days a week |external_link= [http://www.powdermountain.com/ Powder Mountain Winter Resort] }} '''Powder Mountain''' is a [[ski resort]] located just east of [[Eden, Utah]], stretching between [[Weber County, Utah|Weber]] and [[Cache County|Cache]] counties, and only 55 miles from [[Salt Lake City International Airport]]. With over 8,464 acres of skiable terrain, 144 runs, snowcat skiing, side country skiing, backcountry tours and two terrain parks, Powder Mountain is the largest ski resort in the US by skiable acreage. Powder Mountain consistently tops ''Ski Magazine’s'' “Best Value Resort” category, taking home the honor five out of the past six years. With more than 300 inches of annual snowfall, Powder Mountain was ranked #2 for “Snow” and #4 for “Character” while also ranking 9th best by readers for Overall Satisfaction in 2012.http://www.skiutah.com/media/recent_news/powder-mountain-again-ranks-1-in ==History== Powder Mountain had its beginnings as the winter range for Frederick James Cobabe’s sheep herd. Between 1902 and 1948, Cobabe continually accumulated land around [[Eden, Utah]]. Old timers say that his property was severely overgrazed by previous owners and hardly a blade of grass could be found. The watershed was so poor that Wolf Creek dried up each fall. Fred’s soil conservation practices greatly improved the vegetation and Powder Mountain now is known as one of the best watersheds in the [[Wasatch Mountains]].{{cn|date=April 2013}} Fred’s son, Dr. Alvin F. Cobabe, bought the livestock company with its 8,000 acres in 1948. While horseback riding with friends along Lightning Ridge in the 1950s, someone casually mentioned that the terrain would make a great ski resort. The idea rang true with Dr. Cobabe and he began to amass adjacent property adding to the thousands of acres acquired from his father. When the resort opened on February 19, 1972, he owned 14,000 acres. Only the Sundown lift was open during Powder Mountain’s first season. The area was lit for night skiing and a ski school was established. Food was prepared on an outdoor barbecue. The Main Lodge, the Sundown Lodge and the Timberline lift were added to operations in the 1972–73 season. Dr. Alvin Cobabe, at age 88, sold Powder Mountain, Inc in 2006 to Western American Holdings. The resort remained under the same management team, led by Aleta Cobabe, daughter of Alvin, during the 2006–07 season. http://www.powdermountain.com/en/about-mountain/history/ Western American sold Powder Mountain to events company Summit in 2013.[https://www.npr.org/2013/06/18/192674659/why-buy-a-house-when-you-can-buy-a-mountain Why Buy A House When You Can Buy A Mountain?] ==The resort today== Powder Mountain currently has six chair lifts (one triple, four fixed quad, and one detachable quad), and an additional three surface tows. Beyond lift accessed terrain, Powder Mountain also offers all-day Snowcat Powder Safaris, single ride cat skiing and inbound and backcountry guided tours through their Adventure Center. http://www.powdermountain.com/en/adventure/ The slopes on both sides of the road leading up to the resort—known as Powder Country—are served by a bus that will pick riders up at a waiting area halfway down the access road. There is also an $25 per-ride Snowcat service up Lightning Ridge (very close to James Peak). James Peak is one of the premier powder bowl runs in [[Utah]].{{cn|date=April 2013}} Powder Mountain’s terrain within the lift accessible area offers a wide variety of runs for riders of every skill level, including a large assortment of green, blue and black runs. With over 2,500 inbound vertical feet available and over 400 inches of annual snowfall, Powder Mountain is largely considered{{By whom|date=April 2013}} to be one of the premier powder skiing destinations in the world. Powder Mountain also offers ski-in, ski-out condos for rent at the summit, making it a convenient getaway for skiers of all levels. http://www.powdermountainblog.weebly.com ==Timeline== '''1971–72 season''' *Powder Mountain opened with Sundown Lift. *Ski School began. '''1972/73 Season''' *Main Lodge opened. *Sundown Lodge opened. *Timberline lift opened. '''1975/76 Season''' *Hidden Lake Lift added. '''1981/82 Season''' *Shuttle service for employees and for Powder Country started. '''1984/85 Season''' *Powder was the first Utah resort to allow snowboarding. '''1986/87 Season''' [[Image:Powder Mountain Hidden Lake Lodge.JPG|thumb|300px|Hidden Lake Lodge]] *Hidden Lake Day Lodge opened. '''1994/95 Season''' *Sunrise Lift opened. '''1999/2000 Season''' *Paradise Lift, a quad, opened up an additional 1300 acres (5.3 km²) of lift accessed terrain. *Cat skiing moved to Lightning Ridge accessing an additional 700 acres (2.8 km²). *Powder Mountain became the resort with the most skiable terrain in America. '''2006–07 season''' *Hidden Lake lift replaced with a high speed lift. '''2012–13 season''' *In 2012, Summit announced its plans to purchase Powder Mountain with the goal of preserving the throwback character of Powder Mountain while creating a permanent home for the Summit community.http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/money/55393178-79/summit-powder-mountain-owners.html.csp '''2016-17 season''' *Powder Mountain announced in a press release on October 28th, 2016 that they would be adding two new Skytrac Lifts: Village Lift and Mary's Lift. These new lifts will allow guests to access roughly 1,000 more acres of lift served terrain, and will bring the total skiable acreage to 8,464 (including sidecountry and snow cat serviced terrain). http://www.tetongravity.com/story/news/utahs-powder-mountain-embarks-on-largest-expansion-us-history ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.powdermountain.com Powder Mountain's Homepage] *[http://www.skiutah.com The Ski Utah website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060103030102/http://www.firsttracksonline.com/powdermt.htm First Tracks article on Powder Mountain] [[Category:Ski areas and resorts in Utah]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cache County, Utah]] [[Category:Sports venues in Weber County, Utah]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1972]] [[Category:1972 establishments in Utah]]

(Via ARTS Bus Line) |embedded = {{Infobox NRHP | name =The Rose Bowl | embed = yes | nrhp_type=nhl | image = Rose Bowl, panorama.jpg | caption = Rose Bowl, panorama during UCLA-Arizona football game | added = February 27, 1987 | designated_nrhp_type = February 27, 1987[http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceID=1971&resourceType=Structure National Historic Landmarks Program - Rose Bowl] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208051101/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceID=1971&resourceType=Structure |date=2008-12-08 }} United States National Park Service | governing_body = Local | refnum=87000755{{NRISref|2008a}} }} | seating_capacity = all seated 90,888{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/about/history|website=Rose Bowl Stadium|publisher=Rose Bowl Stadium|accessdate=28 November 2014}} | record_attendance = 106,869[https://www.ncaa.org/library/records/football/football_records_book/2002/487-501a.pdf 2002 NCAA Records book - Attendance Records] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409000000/http://www.ncaa.org/library/records/football/football_records_book/2002/487-501a.pdf |date=2008-04-09 }} page 494 (PDF) ([[1973 Rose Bowl]]) }} The '''Rose Bowl''', also known as '''Spieker Field at the Rose Bowl'''[http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/id/20758957/rose-bowl-name-surface-spieker-field-10m-donation-ucla-alum], is an [[United States of America|American]] outdoor athletic [[stadium]], located in [[Pasadena, California]], a northeast suburb of [[Los Angeles]]. Opened in October 1922, the stadium is recognized as a [[National Historic Landmark]] and a California Historic Civil Engineering landmark. At a modern capacity of an all-seated configuration at 90,888 (making it one of the rare stadiums in college football to have such a seating arrangement; many such stadiums have bench-style seating) the Rose Bowl is the [[List of stadiums by capacity|17th-largest stadium in the world]], the [[List of U.S. stadiums by capacity|11th-largest stadium in the United States]], and the [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums|11th largest NCAA stadium]]. One of the most famous venues in sporting history,{{cite web|title=Famed Rose Bowl to host FC Barcelona v LA Galaxy|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/famed-rose-bowl-to-host-fc-barcelona-v-la-galaxy|website=FBBARCELONA.COM|publisher=FC Barcelona|accessdate=9 July 2015}} the Rose Bowl is best known as a [[college football]] venue, specifically as the host of the annual [[Rose Bowl Game]] for which it is named. Since [[1982 UCLA Bruins football team|1982]], it has also served as the home stadium of the [[UCLA Bruins football]] team. The stadium has also hosted five [[Super Bowl]] games, [[Super Bowl#Host stadiums|second most of any venue]]. The Rose Bowl is also a noted [[soccer]] venue, having hosted the [[1994 FIFA World Cup Final]], [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup Final]], and the [[Football at the 1984 Summer Olympics#Gold Medal match|1984 Olympic Gold Medal Match]], as well as numerous [[CONCACAF]] and [[United States Soccer Federation]] matches.{{cite web|title=Rose Bowl Stadium|url=http://www.internationalchampionscup.com/venues/8569e961c2aae489f470#GuFzOYKJHvDzS0O0.97|website=InternationalChampionsCup.com|publisher=International Champions Cup|accessdate=9 July 2015}} The stadium and adjacent Brookside Golf and Country Club are owned by the city of Pasadena and managed by the Rose Bowl Operating Company, a non-profit organization whose board is selected by council members of the city of Pasadena. UCLA and the [[Pasadena Tournament of Roses Association|Pasadena Tournament of Roses]] also have one member on the company board. ==History== ===Design and construction=== [[File:RoseBowl-construction1921.jpg|left|thumb|Construction in 1921; note the original horseshoe shape]] The game now known as the Rose Bowl Game was played at [[Tournament Park]] though January [[1922 Rose Bowl|1922]], about {{convert|3|mi|0|spell=in}} southeast, adjacent to the campus of the [[California Institute of Technology]] (Caltech). The [[Pasadena Tournament of Roses|Pasadena Tournament of Roses Association]], the game's organizer, realized the temporary stands were inadequate for a crowd of more than 40,000, and sought to build a better, permanent stadium. The stadium was designed by architect [[Myron Hunt]] in 1921. His design was influenced by the [[Yale Bowl]] in [[New Haven, Connecticut]], which opened in 1914. The [[Arroyo Seco (Los Angeles County)|Arroyo Seco]] was selected as the location for the stadium. The Rose Bowl was under construction from Feb. 27, 1922 to October 1922.{{cite journal|title=Stadium saucer is begun by workmen|journal=Pasadena Star-News|date=February 28, 1922|page=7}}{{cite journal|title=Vast Stadium Awaits Inaugural Throngs|journal=Los Angeles Times|date=October 8, 1922|volume=XLI|page=II 1}} The nearby [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]] also was under construction during this time and would be completed in May 1923, shortly after the Rose Bowl was completed. Originally built as a horseshoe, the stadium was expanded several times. The southern stands were completed in 1928, enclosing the stadium into a complete bowl. The field's alignment is nearly north-south, offset slightly northwest, and the [[elevation]] at street level is approximately {{convert|830|ft|round=5}} above [[sea level]]. The stadium's name was alternatively "Tournament of Roses Stadium" or "Tournament of Roses Bowl", until being settled as "Rose Bowl" before the [[1923 Rose Bowl]] game,HUGE FLAGSTAFF FOR PASADENA. Enormous Steel Pole 122 and ½ Feet Long Will Stand in Rose Bowl. Los Angeles Times, December 10, 1922. MONDAY afternoon at 2 o'clock the new flagstaff of the Tournament of Roses stadium, now called the Rose Bowl, will be put in place with suitable ceremony under auspices of the Pasadena Lions Club, donor of the pole. in reference to the unusually named (at the time) Yale Bowl. The stadium is extremely difficult to access due to the traffic caused by single-lane residential street access. It has no dedicated parking lot for visitors and parking issues have routinely caused visitors to spend two to three hours completing the last mile to the stadium on game days. In 2016, Rose Bowl contracted [[Parkjockey|ParkJockey]] to streamline parking in and around the stadium. There are also shuttles to help visitors get to the stadium and mobile lights powered by generators to provide visibility for people walking on the golf course at night. ===Dedication, October 1922=== The first game was a regular season contest in 1922, when [[1922 California Golden Bears football team|California]] defeated [[1922 USC Trojans football team|USC]] {{nowrap|12–0}} on October 28. This was the only loss for USC and Cal finished the season undefeated. California declined the invitation to the [[1923 Rose Bowl]] game and USC went instead. The stadium was dedicated officially on January 1, 1923, when USC defeated [[1923 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] {{nowrap|14–3.}} ===Seating=== The stadium seating has been reconfigured several times since its construction in 1922. The South end was filled in to complete the bowl and more seats have been added. The original wooden benches were replaced by aluminum benches in 1969. All new grandstand and loge seats had been installed since 1971.{{Citation | last = Dellins | first = Marc | title = 1989 UCLA FOOTBALL MEDIA GUIDE | place = Los Angeles| publisher = UCLA Sports Information Office | year = 1989 | chapter = The Rose Bowl | page = 254 }} New red seat backs had been added on 22,000 seats prior to the [[1980 Rose Bowl]]. A Rose Bowl improvement was conducted because of UCLA's 1982 move and the [[1984 Summer Olympics]]. This resulted in new seat backs for 50,000 seats. For many years, the Rose Bowl had the largest football stadium capacity in the United States, eventually being surpassed by [[Michigan Stadium]] (107,601).{{cite web|url=http://bentley.umich.edu/athdept/stadium/|title=Michigan Stadium Story|work=umich.edu|accessdate=29 July 2015}}[http://www.mgoblue.com/facilities/article.aspx?id=28642 University of Michigan Official Athletics site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080120092641/http://www.mgoblue.com/facilities/article.aspx?id=28642 |date=2008-01-20 }} – Michigan Stadium The Rose Bowl's maximum stated [[seating capacity]] was 104,091 from 1972 to 1997. Some of the seats closest to the field were never used during this time for UCLA regular season games, and were covered by tarps. Official capacity was lowered following the [[1998 Rose Bowl]]. Slightly different figures are given for the current capacity, for the lower level seats behind the team benches are not used for some events since the spectators can not see through the standing players or others on the field. UCLA reports the capacity at 91,136.''UCLA Football – 2007 UCLA Football (Media Guide)''. UCLA Athletic Department (2007), page 165 (PDF copy available at www.uclabruins.com) The Tournament of Roses reports the capacity at 92,542.[http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/RoseBowl_history.htm Rose Bowl Stadium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907115147/http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/RoseBowl_history.htm |date=2009-09-07 }} – History of the Rose Bowl Stadium The [[2006 Rose Bowl]] game, which was also the BCS championship game, had a crowd of 93,986.[http://www.tournamentofroses.com/roseparade/paradefaqs.asp Tournament of Roses Parade FAQs] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814001636/http://www.tournamentofroses.com/roseparade/paradefaqs.asp |date=2007-08-14 }}. The Rose Bowl Game is a contractual sellout. In 2006, attendance was 93,986. In the 2011 contest between TCU and Wisconsin, the listed attendance is 94,118. As of 2008, the Rose Bowl is the 11th [[List of American football stadiums by capacity|largest football stadium]], and is still the largest stadium that hosts post-season bowl games.[http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/RoseBowl_history.htm Historic information on the Rose Bowl Stadium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907115147/http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/RoseBowl_history.htm |date=2009-09-07 }} For concerts held there, the Rose Bowl holds almost 60,000 people. The stadium's 2014 remodeling removed the lower "lettered row" seats on each side behind the players' benches and provide access in and out of the stadium for the lower sections of the Rose Bowl, restoring its original design. ===Stadium renovations=== [[File:2008-1206-USC-UCLA-009-RB-redblue.JPG|thumb|right|UCLA-USC football game at the Rose Bowl; the 2008 edition marked a return to the tradition of both teams wearing home jerseys]] The press box was updated before the [[1962 Rose Bowl]] with an elevator and two rows. The cost was $356,000. The Press Box was refurbished for UCLA's move in 1982 and the 1984 Summer Olympics. In 2011 and 2012, the press box was undergoing renovation as part of the larger renovation originally budgeted at $152 million in 2010.Toby Zwikel, Noah Gold, Brian Robin, Brener Zwikel & Associates, Inc – [https://web.archive.org/web/20101015204303/http://www.pasadenacal.com/pasadena-press-releases/248--pasadena-city-council-approves-152-million-renovation-of-iconic-rose-bowl-stadium.html Pasadena City Council approves $152 million renovation of iconic Rose Bowl] City of Pasadena, October 12, 2010 Costs had increased to $170 million during construction.Piasecki, Joe – [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/09/renovation-costs-at-rose-bowl-now-estimated-at-170-million.html Renovation Costs at Rose Bowl now estimated at $170 million]. ''Los Angeles Times'', September 23, 2012 Work proceeded during the 2011 football season, and was expected to be completed before the UCLA Bruins' first home game in 2012. Some unforeseen problems had been encountered due to the stadium's age and some renovations done in the early 1990s. Most of the planned renovations were completed in 2013. Because of the increased construction cost, items deferred for the future are additional new restrooms, the historic field hedge, new entry gate structures, and additional new concession stands. The stadium has started "The Brick Campaign" to help pay for some of the cost of the renovations.Rose Bowl America's Stadium, ''Los Angeles Times'' Advertising Supplement, August 29, 2012 The Brick Campaign, completed in 2014, features a large logo of the [[Pasadena Tournament of Roses]] and the donor bricks arranged by universities in front of the south main entrance to the stadium. A large 30 feet tall by 77 feet wide [[Light-emitting diode|LED]] video display board was added to the north end of the stadium as a part of the renovation. ===Court of Champions=== The Court of Champions is at the stadium's south end. Rose Bowl game records along with the names of the coaches and the MVP players, are shown on the plaques attached to the exterior wall. The Hall of Fame statue is also at the Court of Champions. The 2014 renovation allows more plaques to be placed on the wall and floor for future games. ===Terry Donahue Pavilion=== The seven-story [[Terry Donahue]] Pavilion is named for the former UCLA football head coach, who is the most successful coach in UCLA and Pac-12 history. It houses the press boxes, broadcast booths, premium seating, boxes and suites. The radio and TV booths will be renamed "The [[Keith Jackson]] Broadcast Center" in December 2015. Jackson, the former [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC-TV]] sportscaster, coined the phrase "The [[Granddaddy of Them All]]" for the [[Rose Bowl game]]."[http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/legacy/keith-jackson-broadcast-center Keith Jackson Broadcast Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113133651/http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/legacy/keith-jackson-broadcast-center |date=2015-11-13 }}, Rosebowlstadium.com, November 5, 2015 ===''Sports Illustrated'' venue rankings=== In 1999, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' listed the Rose Bowl at number 20 in the Top 20 Venues of the 20th Century.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/centurys_best/news/1999/06/02/top_venues/ SI's Top 20 Venues of the 20th Century]. ''Sports Illustrated'', June 7, 1999 ''"The Rose Bowl is more a postcard than a stadium, designed to seduce pasty Midwesterners with the California fantasy. How many Big Ten fans tuned in on those wintry New Year's Days to gawk at the blooming bougainvillea and started packing their station wagons at halftime? "'' In 2007, Sports Illustrated named the Rose Bowl the number one venue in college sports.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/si_blogs/sioncampus/vent/2007/07/top-10-venues-in-college-sports.html Top 10 College Sports Venues: Number 1 – Rose Bowl] ''Sports Illustrated''. Text: Mallory Rubin. July 13, 2007 ==Football at the Rose Bowl== ===Rose Bowl Game=== {{Main|Rose Bowl Game}} The Rose Bowl stadium is best known in the U.S. for its hosting of the [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]], a [[postseason]] [[college football]] game. The game is played after the [[Tournament of Roses Parade]] on New Year's Day, or, if January 1 is a Sunday, on the following Monday January 2. The stadium's name has given rise to the term "[[bowl game]]" for postseason football games, regardless of whether they are played in a bowl-shaped or "Bowl"-named stadium. The Rose Bowl Game is commonly referred to as "The Granddaddy of Them All" because of its stature as the oldest of all the bowl games. Since its opening, the Rose Bowl stadium has hosted the bowl game every year except the [[1942 Rose Bowl]], when the game was moved to [[Durham, North Carolina]], at the campus of [[Duke University]]. Duke, which played in the game on January 1, volunteered to host the contest because of security concerns on the West Coast in the weeks following the attack on [[Attack on Pearl Harbor|Pearl Harbor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sports-venue.info/NCAAF/Bowls/T_Rose_Bowl_Timeline.html|title=Rose Bowl Timeline|publisher=Pasadena Tournament of Roses|accessdate=2007-11-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080522115924/http://www.sports-venue.info/NCAAF/Bowls/T_Rose_Bowl_Timeline.html|archivedate=2008-05-22|df=}}Zimmerman, Paul "Scene of Rose Bowl Shifted to Durham, N.C." ''Los Angeles Times'', December 16, 1941. Perpetuation of the annual Rose Bowl intersectional football, classic was assured yesterday when the Tournament of Roses officials and Oregon State College accepted the hospitality of Duke University. Since 1945, the Rose Bowl has been the highest attended college football bowl game.NCAA Division 1 football records book. NCAA, 2007 Edition, pages 296-302 Major Bowl Game Attendance ===BCS National Championship=== [[File:2010 BCS Champ.jpg|thumb|240px|[[2009 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas]] and [[2009 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] in January [[2010 BCS National Championship Game|2010]]]] {{Main|BCS National Championship Game}} [[File:2014 BCS Championship.JPG|thumb|240px|[[2013 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] and [[2013 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] in January [[2014 BCS National Championship Game|2014]]]] Starting with the [[1998 NCAA Division I-A football season|1998]] season, the Rose Bowl became part of the [[Bowl Championship Series]] (BCS). The [[2002 Rose Bowl|2002]] and [[2006 Rose Bowl|2006]] games also were the BCS Championship games, matching the #1 and #2 BCS teams in the nation. The [[2010 BCS National Championship Game]] was played six days after the [[2010 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]] game as a completely separate event from the Tournament of Roses, though it managed the event. The stadium hosted the [[2014 BCS National Championship Game]], the final game before the BCS was replaced by the current [[College Football Playoff]], when it celebrated its 100th anniversary of the Rose Bowl game.Beth Harris, [http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9IUVIE00.htm Vizio to be new Rose Bowl sponsor], ''AP'' via ''BusinessWeek'', October 19, 2010 {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- !Season !Game !Date !Visiting team !Points !Home team !Points !Spectators |- | [[2001 NCAA Division I-A football season|2001]] || [[2002 Rose Bowl|2002]] || January 3|| [[2001 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska]] || 14|| '''[[2001 Miami Hurricanes football team|Miami]]''' ||37 ||93,781 |- | [[2005 NCAA Division I-A football season|2005]] || [[2006 Rose Bowl|2006]] || January 4|| '''[[2005 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas]]'''|| 41|| [[2005 USC Trojans football team|USC]]* || 38 || 93,986 |- | [[2009 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2009]] || [[2010 BCS National Championship Game|2010]] || January 7 || [[2009 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas]] || 21 || '''[[2009 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]]''' ||37|| 94,906 |- | [[2013 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2013]] ||  [[2014 BCS National Championship Game|2014]]  || January 6 || [[2013 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] || 31 || '''[[2013 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]]''' || 34 || 94,208 |} ''' ''Note: *USC later vacated all wins during the season.'' Though the Rose Bowl is eligible to bid on hosting the [[College Football Playoff]] [[College Football Playoff National Championship|Championship Game]] in years it is not hosting a semifinal, it has no plans to do so.{{cite web|last1=Fornelli|first1=Tom|title=Rose Bowl will not bid for 2020 College Football Playoff title game|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegefootball/eye-on-college-football/25160363/rose-bowl-will-not-bid-for-2020-title-game|website=CBS Sports|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=8 July 2015}} ===College Football Playoff semifinals=== {{Main|College Football Championship Game}} The Rose Bowl Game is one of the six primary bowls of the [[College Football Playoff]] (CFP), which replaced the BCS effective with the [[2014 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2014]] season. Every three years, the Rose Bowl will match two of the top four teams selected by the system's [[College Football Playoff#Selection Committee|selection committee]] to compete for a spot at the [[College Football Playoff National Championship|national championship]] game. The first CFP semifinal game at the Rose Bowl was the [[2015 Rose Bowl]], whose winner advanced to the [[2015 College Football Playoff National Championship|championship game]] on January 12 at [[AT&T Stadium]] in [[Texas]]. {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- !Season !Rose Bowl !Date !Visiting team !Points !Home team !Points !Spectators |- | [[2014 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2014]] || [[2015 Rose Bowl|2015]] || January 1 || align=left|#3 [[2014 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] || 20 || align=left|#2 '''[[2014 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]]''' || 59 || 91,322 |- | [[2017 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2017]] || [[2018 Rose Bowl|2018]] || January 1 || align=left|#3 '''[[2017 Georgia Bulldogs football team|Georgia]]''' || 54 | align="left" |#2 [[2017 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] || 48 |92,844 |} ''' ===UCLA Bruins football home stadium=== {{Main|UCLA Bruins football}} [[File:UCLA Rose Bowl record.jpg|thumb|Previous edition of Rose Bowl records at Hall of Champions]] The Rose Bowl stadium has been the home football field for [[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]] since [[1982 NCAA Division I-A football season|1982]]. The UCLA Bruins had played their home games at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]] since [[1928 college football season|1928]]. There was an attempt to build a 44,000 seat stadium on campus, at the site where [[Drake Stadium (UCLA)|Drake Stadium]] eventually was built. However, the proposal was blocked by influential area residents, as well as other politicians.Crowe, Jerry – [http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-crowe16-2009nov16,0,1062188.column "There goes the neighborhood: How UCLA stadium bid was scuttled."] ''Los Angeles Times'', November 16, 2009Reich, Ken "Stadium for UCLA Given Support – Architect's Study Cites Project as 'Desirable' STADIUM SUPPORT". ''Los Angeles Times'', November 18, 1965. ''UCLA officials--still reportedly trying to decide whether to recommend the building of a 44,000-seat football stadium on campus--have released details of an architectural feasibility study.'' At the start of the [[1982 NFL season]], with the [[Oakland Raiders]] scheduled to move in, UCLA decided to relocate its home games to the Rose Bowl Stadium.[http://www.uclahistoryproject.ucla.edu/Fun/ThisMonth_AugRosebowl.asp UCLA History Project - This Month in History Aug. 18, 1982 … A gridiron home] – includes a photograph of the 1983 Rose Bowl game from an overhead shot The Bruins went on to play two straight Rose Bowl games in their new home stadium, the [[1983 Rose Bowl]] and the [[1984 Rose Bowl]]. UCLA has participated in five Rose Bowl games since moving to the stadium. The stadium is the host of the [[UCLA–USC rivalry]] football game on even numbered years, alternating with the Coliseum. In the first rivalry game at the stadium between UCLA and USC in 1982, USC fans sat on the west side of the stadium and UCLA fans sat on the east side of the stadium, mirroring an arrangement that existed when the teams shared the Coliseum. Both teams also wore their home uniforms. In 1984, USC fans were moved to the end zone seats, which ended the tradition of shared stadium. Because of the shared arrangement, and the participation of USC in a number of Rose Bowl games, both schools have winning records in each other's home stadium. The Bruins travel 26 miles from campus to Pasadena to play home games, but only 14 miles to their biggest road game at USC every other year. ===Caltech Beavers football home stadium=== [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]], a university located in Pasadena, played most home games in the Rose Bowl from the time of its construction until the school dropped football in [[1993 in sports|1993]]. Caltech jovially claimed to play before the greatest number of empty seats in the nation.''The Discovery of Anti-Matter: The autobiography of [[Carl David Anderson]], The Youngest Man To Win the [[Nobel Prize]]''. Published 1999 by World Scientific ({{ISBN|981-02-3680-8}}) ===Junior Rose Bowl=== The stadium hosted the '''Junior Rose Bowl''' from 1946 to 1971 and 1976 to 1977. Between 1946 and 1966 and 1976 and 1977, the game pitted the [[California Community College Athletic Association|California Junior College]] football champions against the [[National Junior College Athletic Association|NJCAA]] football champions for the national championship. It was organized by the Pasadena Junior Chamber of Commerce. The Junior Rose Bowl became the [[Pasadena Bowl]] from 1967 to 1971; it was billed as the Junior Rose Bowl the first two years, but instead two teams from the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] College Division competed (then later the University Division, usually featuring teams that were not invited to other major bowls). ===1983 Army-Navy game=== The Rose Bowl stadium is the only site west of the Mississippi River to host an [[Army–Navy Game]] ([[1983 in sports|1983]]). The city of Pasadena paid for the traveling expenses of the all students and supporters of both the [[United States Naval Academy|U.S. Naval Academy]] and [[United States Military Academy|U.S. Military Academy]].Clark, N. Brooks – [http://vault.sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1135870/index.htm This Week 12.05.83.] Sports Illustrated, December 5, 1983 The attendance was 81,000.[http://www.athlonsports.com/college-football/4323/no-1-army-vs-navy No. 1 Army vs. Navy] Athlon Sports[http://www.usna.edu/LibExhibits/Archives/Armynavy/An1983.htm Army Navy Football 1983]. Score: Navy 42 – Army 13 | Game played at the Rose Bowl. United States Naval Academy Exhibits The game was brought to the Rose Bowl as there are a large number of military installations and servicemen and women, along with many retired military personnel, on the West Coast. ===Super Bowls=== {{Main|Super Bowl}} The stadium has hosted the [[Super Bowl]] five times. The first was [[Super Bowl XI]] in January 1977, when the [[1976 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]] beat the [[1976 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota Vikings]] 32–14. The game was also played there in 1980 ([[Super Bowl XIV|XIV]]), 1983 ([[Super Bowl XVII|XVII]]), 1987 ([[Super Bowl XXI|XXI]]) and 1993 ([[Super Bowl XXVII|XXVII]]). The Rose Bowl is one of two venues (with [[Stanford Stadium]]) to host a Super Bowl though having never served as the full-time home stadium for an NFL or AFL team (Stanford Stadium hosted one [[1989 San Francisco 49ers season|San Francisco 49ers]] game after the [[1989 Loma Prieta earthquake]]). {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- !Season !Date !Super Bowl !Visiting team !Points !Home team !Points !Spectators |- | {{nfly|1976}} || align=right|January 9, [[1976–77 NFL playoffs|1977]] || [[Super Bowl XI|XI]]|| '''[[1976 Oakland Raiders season|Oakland Raiders]]''' || 32|| [[1976 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota Vikings]] || 14||103,438 |- | {{nfly|1979}} || January 20, [[1979–80 NFL playoffs|1980]] ||[[Super Bowl XIV|XIV]] || [[1979 Los Angeles Rams season|Los Angeles Rams]] || 19|| '''[[1979 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]]''' || 31||103,985 |- | {{nfly|1982}} || January 30, [[1982–83 NFL playoffs|1983]] || [[Super Bowl XVII|XVII]] || [[1982 Miami Dolphins season|Miami Dolphins]] || 17|| '''[[1982 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]]''' || 27||103,667 |- | {{nfly|1986}} || January 25, [[1986–87 NFL playoffs|1987]] || [[Super Bowl XXI|XXI]] || [[1986 Denver Broncos season|Denver Broncos]] || 20|| '''[[1986 New York Giants season|New York Giants]]''' || 39||101,063 |- | {{nfly|1992}} || January 31, [[1992–93 NFL playoffs|1993]] || [[Super Bowl XXVII|XXVII]] || [[1992 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] || 17|| '''[[1992 Dallas Cowboys season|Dallas Cowboys]]''' || 52||  98,374 |} Because the NFL has a policy limiting the hosting of a Super Bowl to metropolitan areas with NFL teams, the Super Bowl has not been played at the Rose Bowl since the [[Los Angeles Rams|Rams]] and [[Oakland Raiders|Raiders]] departed the Los Angeles area in {{nfly|1995}}. The most recent Super Bowl held in southern California was [[Super Bowl XXXVII|XXXVII]] in [[San Diego]] in January [[2002–03 NFL playoffs|2003]]. The next L.A.-based Super Bowl ([[Super Bowl LVI|LVI]]) is scheduled for February 2022 at the Rams' and [[Los Angeles Chargers|Chargers]]' [[Los Angeles Stadium at Hollywood Park|new stadium]] in [[Inglewood, California|Inglewood]] (the Rams returned to Los Angeles in [[2016 Los Angeles Rams season|2016]], the Chargers the [[2017 Los Angeles Chargers season|following year]]). ==Soccer at the Rose Bowl== Though best known as an American football stadium, the Rose Bowl is also one of the most decorated [[Association football|soccer (association football)]] venues in the world. The stadium hosted the prestigious [[1994 FIFA World Cup Final]] (an event watched by over 700 million people worldwide), the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup Final]], and the [[Football at the 1984 Summer Olympics#Gold Medal match|1984 Olympic Gold Medal Match]], making it the only venue in the world to host all three of international soccer's major championship matches.{{cite web|title=Rose Bowl, Los Angeles|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifa-tournaments/classic-stadiums/stadium=5003452/index.html|website=FIFA.com|publisher=FIFA|accessdate=8 July 2015}} The [[United States men's national soccer team]] has played 17 games in the Rose Bowl, the [[United States national soccer team results#Results by Home Stadium|fourth most of any venue]]. It has also hosted [[MLS Cup 1998]] and the [[2002 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final|2002]] and [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final]]s. [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]] has played a number of friendlies in the stadium against nations other than the United States. In the past, it was also the home ground of two [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] clubs, the [[Los Angeles Wolves]] in 1968 and the [[Los Angeles Aztecs]] in 1978 and 1979. From 1996 through 2002, the stadium was the home ground of [[Major League Soccer]] club [[LA Galaxy|Los Angeles Galaxy]], who still host occasional matches there.{{cite web|title=Famed Rose Bowl to host FC Barcelona v LA Galaxy|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/first-team/detail/article/famed-rose-bowl-to-host-fc-barcelona-v-la-galaxy|website=FCBARCELONA.COM|publisher=FC Barcelona|accessdate=8 July 2015}} ===Major global soccer tournaments === The Rose Bowl is one of two stadiums to have hosted the [[FIFA World Cup]] finals for both men and women. The Rose Bowl hosted the men's final in [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]] and the women's final in [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup|1999]]. (The only other stadium with this honor is the [[Råsunda Stadium]] near [[Stockholm]], Sweden, which hosted the men's final in [[1958 FIFA World Cup|1958]] and the women's final in [[1995 FIFA Women's World Cup|1995]].) Both Rose Bowl finals were scoreless after [[extra time]] and decided on [[penalty shootout (football)|penalty shootouts]]; [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] defeating [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup Final]], and the [[United States women's national soccer team|United States]] defeating [[China women's national football team|China]] in the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup Final|1999 women's final]].{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/archive/edition=84/results/matches/match=3104/report.html|title=1994 FIFA World Cup Final |date=1994-07-17|work=FIFA.com|accessdate=2009-07-07}}{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=103/edition=4644/matches/match=22183/report.html|title=1999 FIFA Womens World Cup Final |date=1999-07-10|work=FIFA.com|accessdate=2009-07-07}} The Rose Bowl also hosted group stage matches of the [[Copa América Centenario]] in 2016.http://www.ca2016.com/matches It also hosted several matches including the final of the 1984 Olympics men's soccer tournament. On July 27, 2016, the Rose Bowl hosted a [[2016 International Champions Cup]] match between [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. Chelsea won the match 1-0. The Rose Bowl also hosted a [[2018 International Champions Cup]] match between [[F.C. Barcelona]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur]] where Barcelona won 5-3 in penalty kicks after a 2-2 draw. It has also regularly featured [[CONCACAF Gold Cup]] matches including two finals. The Rose Bowl is a candidate to host matches in the [[2026 FIFA World Cup]], and will be a venue in the [[2028 Summer Olympics]].http://la24-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/assets/pdf/LA2024-canditature-part2_english.pdf ===1994 FIFA World Cup matches=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; Another local event is the Rose Bowl Flea Market held the second Sunday of each month, on the stadium parking lots. Hosted by promoter R.G. Canning, it claims to be the largest [[Flea market]] on the West Coast.{{cite web|title=Rose Bowl General Information|url=http://www.rgcshows.com/RoseBowl.aspx|publisher=R.G. Canning Attractions|accessdate=8 July 2015}} The stadium host the annual "Turkey Tussle" homecoming football game between [[John Muir High School]] and [[Pasadena High School (California)|Pasadena High School]], in early November. The Rose Bowl hosted its annual graduation ceremonies for Blair High School, John Muir High School and Pasadena High School until 1984, before staging it at the individual schools until 1998. Currently all three high schools along with John Marshall Fundamental School held their graduation ceremonies at the [[Pasadena Civic Auditorium]] in early June. ===1932 Summer Olympics=== {{main|Cycling at the 1932 Summer Olympics}} The Rose Bowl was the [[Cycling at the 1932 Summer Olympics|track cycling]] venue for the [[1932 Summer Olympics]].[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1932/1932s.pdf 1932 Summer Olympics official report.] p. 74. ===Concerts=== {| class="wikitable" style=font-size:100% style="text-align:center" |- ! width=12% style="background:#ED1C24; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #008348;"|Date ! width=10% style="background:#ED1C24; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #008348;"|Performer(s) ! width=10% style="background:#ED1C24; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #008348;"|Opening act(s) ! width=16% style="background:#ED1C24; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #008348;"|Tour/Event ! width=10% style="background:#ED1C24; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #008348;"|Attendance ! width=20% style="background:#ED1C24; color:#FFFFFF; border:2px solid #008348;"|Notes |- | September 15, 1968[http://www.bbhc.com/bbbase.html Big Brother in Concert] | [[Big Brother and the Holding Company]] | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} | {{n/a}} |- | June 6, 1982{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WCQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT70&dq=billboard+boxscore+rose+bowl&hl=pl&sa=X&ei=Z2HmU6f-JPHY7AbU24CwDg&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=billboard%20boxscore%20rose%20bowl&f=false|title=Billboard|work=google.pl|accessdate=29 July 2015}}[http://waddywachtelinfo.com/PeaceSundayConcert.html Peace Sunday: We Have a Dream Concert 1982] | {{collapsible list | title = Performers | [[Gil Scott-Heron]]

[[Jay Z]] |rowspan="2"|[[Chloe X Halle]] and [[DJ Khaled]] |rowspan="2"|[[On the Run II Tour]] |rowspan="2"| 106,550 |{{n/a}} |- |September 23, 2018 |{{n/a}} |- |May 11, 2019 |The Rolling Stones |TBA |[[No Filter Tour]] | | |- |} ===Other events=== The stadium was used for [[midget car racing]] in the 1940s.{{cite journal|title=The Speedways|journal=URA Third Annual Midget Auto Racing Year Book|date=1946|page=49|publisher=Pacific Coast Speedway News}} The stadium held its first country music festival in June 1981, named A Day in the Country The event was produced by Richard Flanzer of AtlanticPacific Music. The stadium hosted the 2007 [[Drum Corps International]] World Championships August 7 through August 11, 2007. The Rose Bowl was the final stadium to host the championship before DCI moved their corporate offices to [[Indianapolis]] with the championships being held at [[Lucas Oil Stadium]] until at least 2018. This was the first time the DCI championships had ever been held west of [[Denver]], [[Colorado]] in the 45-year history of DCI. It hosted auditions for the top American television show, ''[[American Idol]]'', on August 8, 2006. The stadium has also been used as part of the music video shoot for the song "[[The Last Song (The All-American Rejects song)|The Last Song]]", the second single released by the American rock band [[The All-American Rejects]], which features the band performing the song in the middle of the stadium to an empty crowd. The stadium's Court of Champions was the site of a "Roadblock" from [[The Amazing Race 17|season 17]] of the CBS reality TV show ''[[The Amazing Race]]'' where teams had to help decorate three sections of the [[Tournament of Roses Parade themes|theme float]] for the 2011 New Year's Day [[Tournament of Roses Parade|Rose Parade]]. In November 1997, the [[International Churches of Christ]] (Los Angeles) gathered at the Rose Bowl for their Worship Service, with an attendance of 17,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.kipmckean.com/#_Toc185599053|title=Kipmckean.com – Get Your Answers Here!|work=Kip McKean|accessdate=29 July 2015}} ==Present status== [[File:CardStunt-010104-RoseBowl.jpg|thumb|right|Large [[card stunt]]{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tc6hFmhOxxw|title=2004 Rose Bowl - World's Largest American Flag|date=15 May 2007|work=YouTube|accessdate=29 July 2015}} performed at the 2004 Rose Bowl Game viewed from the Southeast corner]] The Rose Bowl and adjacent golf course are managed by the Rose Bowl Operating Company, a non-profit organization whose board is selected by council members of the City of Pasadena. UCLA and the Pasadena Tournament of Roses also have one member on the company board. The Rose Bowl stadium itself runs on a yearly operational loss.Greg Johnson, [http://www.latimes.com/sports/college/usc/la-sp-bowlfixes1jan01,1,322325,full.story?coll=la-headlines-sports-coll-usc $300-million fixer-upper], ''Los Angeles Times'', January 1, 2007. While it generates funds with the annual lease with UCLA ($1.5 million), the [[Tournament of Roses]] ($900,000), and a regularly hosted flea market ($900,000), it makes up the loss by relying on funds generated by the adjacent city-owned [[Brookside Golf Course|golf course]] ($2 million). While the stadium is able to keep operating in this financial set-up, it is unable to finance many of the capital improvements it needs to be considered a modern facility, including new seats, wider aisles, additional exits, a wider concourse, a renovated press box, a state-of-the-art video [[scoreboard]], new field lighting, additional suites and a club. The estimated cost for such improvements ranges from $250 million and $300 million. The stadium currently has long-term leases with its two major tenants, the [[Pasadena Tournament of Roses]] (2019) and UCLA (2023). In 2006, the Rose Bowl and the City of Pasadena launched a $16.3 million capital improvement program that will benefit both UCLA and the Tournament of Roses. New locker rooms for both UCLA and visiting teams, as well as a new media interview area were constructed. In April 2009, The Rose Bowl Operating Company unveiled a Rose Bowl Strategic Plan, which addressed the objectives to improve public safety; enhance fan experience; maintain national historic landmark status; develop revenue sources to fund long-term improvements; and enhance facility operations. On October 11, 2010, the Pasadena City Council approved a $152 million financing plan for the major renovation of the stadium. Groundbreaking ceremonies for the first of three phases of the project was held on January 25, 2011. The newly constructed video board was used for the June 25, [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final]]. ===NFL=== {{Main|History of the National Football League in Los Angeles}} Since losing both its local teams in the Los Angeles market in 1995, the [[National Football League]] had been looking to either start or relocate a franchise to the Los Angeles area. One of the strong candidates was a renovated Rose Bowl. However, after many years of varying offers, no deal could be struck between the NFL owners, the stadium's owner, and the City of Pasadena, following a vote of disapproval by its residents in November 2006. On November 19, 2012, Pasadena officials approved a proposal which could allow an NFL team to temporarily play in the Rose Bowl.{{cite web|url=http://www.pasadenasun.com/the626now/pasadenasu-20121120,0,1610674.story |title=Pasadena OKs plan that may bring NFL team to the Rose Bowl |publisher=[[Pasadena Sun]] |date=2012-11-20 |accessdate=2011-11-25 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.ci.pasadena.ca.us/Rose_Bowl_EIR/ |title=Temporary Use of the Rose Bowl Stadium by the National Football League |publisher=City of Pasadena |date=2012-11-09 |accessdate=2011-11-25 }} The Rose Bowl, however, has not acted as a home field for an NFL team. When the [[Los Angeles Rams]] moved from [[St. Louis]] prior to the 2016 NFL season, the Rose Bowl was considered as a temporary home before the Rams ultimately settled on playing in USC's [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]], the Rams' home from 1946 to 1979. ==Seating and attendance records== *'''Rose Bowl Game records''': [[1973 Rose Bowl]], January 1, 1973, Attendance: 106,869. Number 1 ranked and undefeated USC vs. number 3 Ohio State. This is the stadium record, as well as the NCAA bowl game record. The smallest Rose Bowl game crowd in the stadium was the [[1934 Rose Bowl]] with 35,000 in attendance to see Columbia defeat Stanford. Three days of rain had turned the stadium into a small lake, and it rained on New Year's Day in 1934, one of the few times in the history of the tournament.Palladino, Lisa – [http://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/jul05/obituaries2.php OBITUARIES: Cliff Montgomery ’34, Rose Bowl Quarterback] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070903190129/http://www.college.columbia.edu/cct/jul05/obituaries2.php |date=2007-09-03 }}. ''Columbia College Today'', July 2005 The largest crowd to watch a Rose Bowl Game after the [[1998 Rose Bowl]] and seating reconfiguration, was 95,173 in the [[2014 Rose Bowl]]. *'''NFL Super Bowl record:''' [[Super Bowl XIV]], Pittsburgh Steelers – Los Angeles Rams, January 20, 1980, Attendance: 103,985. This is an NFL post-season record.[http://www.superbowl.com/news/story/9203984 Showdown in Motown] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070701113331/http://www.superbowl.com/news/story/9203984 |date=2007-07-01 }} by Gil Brant, Feb. 2, 2006 This also stood as an overall NFL record until broken by a 1994 Pre-season game played at [[Estadio Azteca]] (Aztec Stadium) in Mexico City.Tom Weir – [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/games/2005-10-03-cardinals-niners_x.htm Cardinals deep-six 49ers in historic tilt in Mexico]. October 3, 2005, USA Today. Total attendance for record reguklar season game in Mexico City Azteca Stadium is 103,467 breaking the record of 102,368 who saw the Rams play the 49ers on Nov. 10, 1957, at the Los Angeles Coliseum.Tom Weir – [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2005-09-29-nfl-mexico-cover_x.htm Mexico gets ready for football, not futbol]. September 25, 2005, ''USA Today''. quote:A 1994 Houston-Dallas exhibition drew a still-standing NFL record 112,376 to Estadio Azteca *'''[[1984 Summer Olympics]]''' (Games of the XXIII Olympiad) [[Football at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Football (Soccer) Tournament]] – France defeated Brazil 2-0 in the final to win the gold medal on August 11. The attendance was 101,799 setting a record for the largest crowd for a soccer game held in the United States (since broken by a 2014 Manchester United-Real Madrid exhibition at the [[Michigan Stadium]] in [[Ann Arbor, Michigan]] which drew 109,318). The attendance was also the Olympic football record until the Final of the [[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2000 Olympic Football Tournament]] at the [[Stadium Australia]] in [[Sydney]] which drew 104,098.[https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/mensolympic/sydney2000/matches/round=3955/match=20468/index.html 2000 Olympic Games Football] *'''College football regular season record:''' [[UCLA–USC rivalry|UCLA–USC]], November 19, 1988, Attendance: 100,741.''UCLA Football – 2007 UCLA Football (Media Guide)''. UCLA Athletic Department (2007), page 149 (PDF copy available at www.uclabruins.com). Note that the UCLA Bruins have played in six Rose Bowl games with larger crowds: 1956, 1976, 1983, 1984, 1986 and 1994. Undefeated second-ranked USC (9–0) and quarterback [[Rodney Peete]] met sixth-ranked UCLA (9–1) and quarterback [[Troy Aikman]] with a berth in the Rose Bowl Game on the line. Since the 1998 renovations, the largest regular season crowd was for the 2002 UCLA-USC game, with an attendance of 91,084. The largest attendance for a UCLA game, with an opponent other than USC, is 88,804, for the 2000 game against the [[Michigan Wolverines]]. The first game played at the Rose Bowl, on October 28, 1922 between USC and Cal had an attendance of 35,000.USC 2012 Football Media Guide *'''Professional soccer record:''' June 16, 1996: In an historic doubleheader witnessed by 92,216 fans, the U.S. National Team plays Mexico for the championship of U.S. Cup '96 followed by the conference leaders [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] vs. [[Tampa Bay Mutiny]]. The crowd was the largest ever to see a U.S. professional soccer league match. *'''[[1994 FIFA World Cup]]:''' [[1994 FIFA World Cup Final|The final]], held on July 17 saw [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] defeat [[Italy national football team|Italy]] 3-2 after a penalty shootout. Attendance was 94,194. *'''[[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup]]:''' [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup Final|The final]] on July 10, 1999 was the most attended women's sports event in history with an official attendance of 90,185. The [[United States women's national soccer team|USA]] defeated [[China women's national football team|China]] 5-4 in a [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]]. *'''[[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]: '''93,420 fans saw Mexico defeating the United States 4-2 in the [[2011 CONCACAF Gold Cup Final|2011 Gold Cup]] Championship match on June 25, 2011. *'''Soccer, exhibition match:''' On August 1, 2009, an attendance of 93,137 showed up when [[FC Barcelona]] defeated the [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] 2-1 in an exhibition match, making it the largest soccer attendance in the United States since the 1994 World Cup.[http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2009/aug/02/fc-barcelona-tops-galaxy-in-front-of-93137-at/ FC Barcelona tops Galaxy in front of 93,137 at Rose Bowl] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090811073908/http://www.venturacountystar.com/news/2009/aug/02/fc-barcelona-tops-galaxy-in-front-of-93137-at/ |date=2009-08-11 }} The Tour 2014 game between [[Manchester United]] vs. Los Angeles Galaxy had a crowd of 86,432 on July 23, 2014 after recent renovation of the stadium.Steve Ramirez, [http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/sports/20140723/manchester-united-routs-la-galaxy-7-0-at-pasadenas-rose-bowl "Manchester United routs L.A. Galaxy 7-0 at Pasadena's Rose Bowl"], ''Pasadena Star-News'', July 23, 2014. *'''Concert:''' British-Irish boyband, One Direction played 3 sold out nights at the Rose Bowl in September 2014 on the same tour making them the first act ever to accomplish this. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==Notes== * November 17, 2012 – The Rose Bowl press box became known as the [[Terry Donahue]] Pavilion in the fall, 2013.[http://www.uclabruins.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/111712aab.html Rose Bowl Stadium Renames Press Box Terry Donahue Pavilion] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121119011327/http://www.uclabruins.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/111712aab.html |date=2012-11-19 }}, UCLABruins.com, November 17, 2012 Donahue is the winningest coach in the history of the [[Pac-12 Conference]] (known as the Pacific-10 during his coaching career). * June 8, 2013 – Ribbon cutting ceremony for the opening of the new pavilion with Congresswoman [[Judy Chu]] and Mayor [[Bill Bogaard]] * July 7, 2013 – A record 566 [[mariachi]]s performed at the half-time of the first round [[2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup|2013 Gold Cup]] game between Mexico and Panama.David Zahniser, [http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-mariachi-guinness-world-record-20130707,0,5876405.story Mariachi Guinness World Record broken at Rose Bowl], ''Los Angeles Times'', July 7, 2013 ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category-inline|Rose Bowl}} * {{Official website|http://www.rosebowlstadium.com/}} {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title= Site of the

revision.text:
{{ infobox venue | stadium_name = Royal College Sports Complex | nickname = | image = | pushpin_map = Sri Lanka Colombo Greater | location = [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka]] | coordinates = {{Coord|6|54|10|N|79|51|50|E|type:landmark_region:LK|display=inline,title}} | capacity = 12500 | broke_ground = | opened = May 10, 2001 | owner = [[Royal College Colombo]] | operator = [[Royal College Union]] | surface = Grass | dimensions = | construction_cost = Eight million rupees | architect = | tenants = }} '''Royal College Sports Complex''' is the [[rugby union]] grounds of [[Royal College Colombo]], it was formerly known as the '''Royal College Rugby Grounds'''. It is home to multi-use stadium and sports complex. Built in 2000, with funds from the [[Royal College Union]] (RCU), current students and parents; it is managed by a Board of Management appointed by the RCU.<ref>[http://sundaytimes.lk/010506/sportsm.html Opening of Royal College Sports Complex]</ref>
==History== The land on the eastern side of Reid Avenue, was part of the [[Colombo Racecourse]] and the Colombo Turf Club. During [[World War II]] it was the site of the [[Colombo Racecourse Airstrip|RAF airstrip]]. When horse racing declined after gambling was outlawed in the 1950s Colombo Racecourse and its land fell into disuse and was taken over by the government. The large land extent was segmented and distributed to government entities. Royal College Colombo, received a four-acre plot which became the ''Royal College Rugby Grounds''.
In 2000, work began at the rugby grounds for a state of the art sports complex up to international standards to host multiple sports and a modern gymnasium. The indoor stadium houses a 450 seating capacity along with two squash courts with a 150-seat capacity and a badminton courts with 250 seats. In 2013 an additional seating tier, the "Royal -Brandix Sky Pavilion", was constructed increasing the outdoor arena capacity to 12,500 including the terraces.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ft.lk/article/158160/Royal-Brandix-Sky-Pavilion-opens-at-RCSC|title = Royal-Brandix Sky Pavilion opens at RCSC|website = www.ft.lk|access-date = 2016-04-25}}</ref> The complex also boasts a 120 unit car park with basement parking.
==Sports== Royal College Sports Complex grounds serves as a venue for [[rugby union]], [[association football|football]], [[baseball]] and [[hockey]]. The indoor stadium is a venue for [[squash (sport)|squash]], [[badminton]], [[basketball]], [[volleyball]] and [[boxing]].
==Major Events== *[[Bradby Shield Encounter]] *[[Sri Lankan National Badminton Championships]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.spirit.lk/?t=fs&nid=2011052615182173 Another Closely Contested Bradby Shield]
[[Category:Royal College, Colombo|Sports Complex]] [[Category:Sports venues in Colombo]]
{{SriLanka-sports-venue-stub}}

'''Rugby union in Rotuma''' is a major sport.<ref name=Fatiaki>Fatiaki, Anselmo ''Rotuma, hanuạ pumue'' p19 (1991, [[University of the South Pacific]]. Institute of Pacific Studies, {{ISBN|982-02-0035-0}})</ref> [[Rotuma]] is a dependency of [[Fiji]], although one with a distinctive culture and language, more related to its neighbours in [[Tonga]] and [[Samoa]].
The [[Fiji Rugby Football Union]] is the governing body of [[rugby union]] in Rotuma.
==History== Rugby was introduced to Rotuma at the turn of the 20th century, by sailors, and New Zealand missionaries.
In 1910, a combined America Universities rugby team comprising mostly players from California, [[Stanford University|Stanford]], and the [[University of Nevada, Reno|University of Nevada]] went on a tour of [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], as well as Fiji and Rotuma. The underdog American side upset both Rotorua RFC and Auckland RU, which came as a great surprise to the international rugby community.
[[Rugby Sevens]] has been a sport in the [[South Pacific Games]] since the late 1990s.
==See also== *[[Jono Gibbes]] (maternal side), a New Zealand rugby union player. *[[Graham Dewes]], former Fiji rugby union player.<ref>[http://www.hawaii.edu/oceanic/rotuma/os/sports/sports0710.htm Rotuman Sports News from Bruce Tizard-Varcoe in England (30 September 2007)]</ref> * [[National Rugby League|NRL]] player [[John Sutton (rugby league)|John Sutton]]. * [[Gabriel Penjueli]]<ref name=Fkafoa>Wesley, Fred [http://www.rotuma.net/os/biographies/Freddy_Kafoa/Freddy_Kafoa.htm An island, rugby and hope] Fijitimes Online (12 October 2006)</ref> * [[Maka Kafoa]]<ref name=Fkafoa/> * [[Freddy Kafoa]]<ref name=Fkafoa/> * [[Chloe Butler]] *[[Rebecca Tavo]] *[[Nigel Simpson]] *[[Rocky Khan]] *[[Ravai Fatiaki]], a Fiji rugby union player. *[[Sarafu Fatiaki]], former [[National Rugby League|NRL]] player for the [[Penrith Panthers]].
==External links== * http://www.rotuma.net/os/sports/sports2009/sports0901.htm * http://www.springerlink.com/content/x566621440657009/ * http://www.rotumabrisbane.com/
==References== <references/>
{{Rugby union outside WC}} {{Oceania in topic|Rugby union in}}

revision.text:
: ''Not to be confused with [[shirts versus skins]].''
A '''skins game''' is a type of scoring for various sports. It has its origins in [[golf]] but has been adapted for [[disc golf]], [[curling]] and [[bowling]].
==Golf== In [[golf]], a skins event has players compete for prize money on each individual hole.
===Skins Game, PGA Tour=== {{main|Skins Game (PGA Tour)}} There was an annual skins game for male professional golfers which took place in November or December each year after the end of the official [[PGA Tour]] season (1983–2008). It was recognized by the PGA Tour but did not count towards the official money list.
===Telus Skins Game=== {{Main|Telus Skins Game}} There is an annual skins game in Canada for male professional golfers which takes place in June or July each year. It is recognized by the PGA Tour but does not count towards the official money list. It is currently sponsored by [[Telus]] and is officially known as the Telus World Skins Game, hosted at a different golf course each year within Canada.
Over the past two years the [[Telus Skins Game]] has also incorporated a theme, which has been a "world" theme. The "world" theme incorporates 5 golfers located from different regions across the globe (5 golfers from different countries).
===Notes=== The popularity of the tournament led to the term ''skins game'' being used to refer to progressive jackpot events where if a prize is not won, it is carried over to the next round for a combined jackpot.
At least in the early versions of [[Jack Nicklaus 4|the Jack Nicklaus Golf series of computer games]], players were given a choice of [[stroke play]] or Skins rules (and in the initial set-up of a game, could set any value for any hole).
==Curling== A skins game format has also been adapted to the game of [[curling]]. In this format, teams play for ends, not scoring within an end, though points (or in some competitions, prize money as in golf's version) may be assigned to each end. To win an end, the team that has "the hammer" — the one which throws the last stone in the end, an inherent advantage — must score at least two points (under normal scoring rules) to win the end. The other team may win the end by stealing one point. If the team with the hammer gets only one point or the end is blanked, then the game points or prize money associated with that end carry over to the next, as with the golf skins game. If there are unclaimed skins after the final end, they are usually played off with a "draw to the button" — each team throws a single stone into an empty house (target), with the stone coming closest to the button (center) winning.
Scoring in curling skins games is done in one of two methods: in one method, an "S" is denoted if a team wins a skin, and a "C" is denoted for the team with the hammer if there is a carryover. In any event, a "0" is denoted for the other team, and an asterisk is placed beside the team with the hammer. In the other method, an "X" is denoted if a team wins a skin, and a "0" is denoted if the skin is carried over (under the team with the hammer), with the other team's entry for the end being blank. This method, however, does not keep track of which team will have the hammer in an end (which instead must be determined based on the score markings).
The [[Continental Cup of Curling]] is the best-known bonspiel to utilize the skins format. In this bonspiel, the skins portion is played for a total of 30 points, with point values assigned to each end as follows: One half point each for the first six ends, one point each for the seventh and eighth ends. There are 6 skins games with 5 skins available each game. These points are combined with those earned in earlier matches of mixed doubles, singles skills and traditional team games to determine the winner of the Cup. <ref>[http://www.curling.ca/2015continentalcup-en/scoring/ Continental Cup of Curling official website]</ref>
The [[TSN Skins Game]] was an annual tournament which featured skins games. The Network was restarted in 2007.
The Skins Game was thought to have been invented by [[Doug Maxwell]], a noted innovator in the sport. Early skins games often consisted of ten ends, the standard length of a modern competitive curling game. Today, largely on account of the influence of television, eight end games (the usual length of a recreational or semi-competitive curling game) has become the standard for skins competition.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.curling.ca/2015continentalcup-en|Continental Cup of Curling official website}} * [http://www.telusskins.com TELUS Skins Game Official Website]
{{Golf|state=collapsed}}

::''For more in depth, albeit general information see [[Football in Nigeria]].'' {{Infobox sport overview | boxwidth = 250 | title = Women's football in Nigeria | image = | imagesize = 240px | image_alt = | caption = | union = [[Nigeria Football Federation]] | country = Nigeria | sport = football | noncountry = | teamlabel1 = | nationalteam = [[Nigeria women's national football team|Women's national team]] | teamlabel2 = | repteam = | nickname = | first = | registered = | clubs = | national_list = [[Nigerian Women's Cup]] | club_list = [[Nigeria Women Premier League]] | intl_list = [[Football at the Summer Olympics|Olympics]]
[[FIFA Women's World Cup]](National Team)
[[Africa Women Cup of Nations]](National Team) | match = | league = }} '''Women's football in Nigeria''' has been increasing in popularity for many years.{{cite news|title= Nigeria: Okocha Commends Growth of Womens Football|publisher= [[AllAfrica.com]]|date=|url= http://allafrica.com/stories/201101210798.html|accessdate=2012-07-30}}{{cite news|title= In African Women’s Soccer, Homophobia Remains an Obstacle|publisher=The New York Times|date=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/23/sports/soccer/in-african-womens-soccer-homophobia-remains-an-obstacle.html?_r=0|accessdate=2015-03-24}} The [[Nigerian Women's Championship]] is funded by the government to improve the [[Nigeria women's national football team]].{{cite news|title= Nigeria to overhaul women's football|publisher= [[Nigerian Tribune]]|date=|url= http://www.tribune.com.ng/sun/sports/7687-nigeria-to-overhaul-womens-football|accessdate=2012-07-30}}{{cite news|title= Nigeria: Women's Football - Club Owners Plan Big for Jonathan|publisher= [[AllAfrica.com]]|date=|url= http://allafrica.com/stories/201105110735.html|accessdate=2012-07-30}}{{cite news|title= Letter from Africa: Why Nigeria's women out-kick the men|publisher= [[BBC]]|date=|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-36085884|accessdate=2016-07-18}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38230355|title=African women's champions Nigeria in fight for 'welfare'|date=9 December 2016|publisher=|accessdate=28 February 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/01/nff-inaugurates-nigeria-women-football-league-board/|title=NFF inaugurates Nigeria Women Football League board - Vanguard News|date=5 January 2017|publisher=|accessdate=28 February 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/blog/football-africa/80/post/3012104/nigeria-africa-women-cup-of-nations-win-shows-interest-is-on-the-up|title=Nigeria's Africa Women Cup of Nations win shows interest is on the up|publisher=|accessdate=28 February 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/african-artistry-and-anger-at-the-womens-world-cup/|title=African Artistry and Anger at the Women’s World Cup|publisher=|accessdate=13 July 2017|via=The Nation}}{{cite web|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/nigeria-womens-world-cup-underdog-2015-6?r=US&IR=T|title=Nigeria — the last-ranked team in the Group of Death — is the most badass team at the Women's World Cup|publisher=|accessdate=13 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-36085884|title=Letter from Africa: Why Nigeria's women out-kick the men|date=20 April 2016|publisher=|accessdate=13 July 2017|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ==History== Numerous Nigerian cities hosted women's football teams by 1960. Multiple efforts were made in the 1960s to start women's football clubs in South Africa, but they proved fleeting. The 1970s saw some growth, with new women's leagues in Nigeria and an expansion of women's football into Western African countries, including Senegal. One local club in [[Dakar]] played a match against an Italian club in 1974; five years later, an early match between African nations was played by the Dakar side and a team from Guinea.{{cite book|author=Peter Alegi|title=African Soccerscapes: How a Continent Changed the World's Game|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NrW50yHkr0EC|accessdate=3 April 2016|date=2 March 2010|publisher=Ohio University Press|isbn=978-0-89680-278-0|page=120}} Despite a lack of support from Nigerian officials, 28 clubs played women's football in the country by 1989, and [[Nigeria women's national football team|Nigeria's national team]] competed in the [[1991 FIFA Women's World Cup|1991 Women's World Cup]]. More women began playing football in the 1990s, in countries like Nigeria and South Africa. In 1998, CAF introduced an official [[Africa Women Cup of Nations|African Women's Championship]], following two unofficial versions of the tournament earlier in the 1990s; host country Nigeria won, beginning a stretch of five consecutive titles in the event. The next year, the squad reached the quarterfinals of the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup|1999 Women's World Cup]].Alegi, pp. 121–123. ==See also== *[[Football in Nigeria]] *[[Nigeria women's national football team]] ==References== {{Women's football in Africa}} [[Category:Women's football in Nigeria| ]] {{footy-stub}} {{Nigeria-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox Theatre |name = Worcester Memorial Auditorium |image = Worcester Aud.jpg |caption = |address = Lincoln Square |city = [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]], [[Massachusetts]] |country = [[United States]] |designation = |latitude = |longitude = |architect = [[Frederic Charles Hirons|Frederic C. Hirons]] and [[L. W. Briggs Company]]<ref>http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=WOR.372</ref> |owner = |capacity = 3,508<ref name=Mag>[http://organweb.com/specs/worc-aud-5-2002-worc-mag.html Kiss the AUD Goodbye] [[Worcester Magazine]]. May 10, 2002</ref> |type = |opened = 1933<ref name=Aud>[http://www.telegram.com/article/20090920/NEWS/909200412/1101 The Aud Future] [[Worcester Telegram & Gazette]]. September 20, 2009</ref> |yearsactive = |rebuilt = |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = vacant |website = }} [[File:Worcester Memorial Auditorium - Main Mural.jpg|thumb|Main mural by Leon Kroll (1938-1941)]] [[File:Worcester Memorial Auditorium - Hall Doors.jpg|thumb|Memorial Hall doors]]
'''Worcester Memorial Auditorium''' (also known simply as '''Worcester Auditorium''') is a multi-purpose [[arena]] located at Lincoln Square in [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]], [[Massachusetts]]. Built in 1933, as a [[World War I]] [[War memorial]] in the form of a multi-purpose hall,<ref name=Aud /> the Auditorium has a {{convert|116|ft|m|adj=mid|-wide}},<ref name=Mag /> [[proscenium]]. It was added to the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1980 as part of the [[Institutional District]].<ref name=NRHP>{{cite web|url=http://mhc-macris.net/Details.aspx?MhcId=WOR.M|title=NRHP nomination for Institutional District|publisher=Commonwealth of Massachusetts|accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref>
In 2009 Lincoln Square was listed as one of the "Most Endangered Historic Resources" in the state by [[Preservation Massachusetts]]<ref>[http://www.telegram.com/article/20090922/NEWS/909220365/1101It ''Lincoln Square is "Endangered Historic Resource"''] [[Worcester Telegram & Gazette]] September 22, 2009</ref> because of the three historical buildings in the square that are all empty or underutilized. The Auditorium was most recently used to house Massachusetts State Trial Court records and a small after-school program.<ref name=Aud />
==History== The Worcester Auditorium was designed as a [[World War I]] [[War memorial]] in the form of a multi-purpose hall.<ref name=Aud /> The building is built in the [[Classical Revival]] style, but with [[Art Deco]] [[bas-relief]] ornamentation.<ref>[http://www.preservationworcester.org/pages/tourmain.html#Anchor-Th-20413 Main Street Virtual Tour], [[Preservation Worcester]]. Accessed September 24, 2009</ref> The interior [[murals]] in the Auditorium were created by the artist [[Leon Kroll]],<ref name=Aud /> and took three years to complete between 1938 and 1941.<ref>[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0A1EFD3459167B93CAA8178ED85F458485F9 Murals Ready At Worcester; Leon Kroll Completes War Memorial and Dedication Is Set for May 28th], [[New York Times]]. May 18, 1941. Accessed September 24, 2009</ref> When finished the main mural was the largest of its kind in the United States.<ref name= Telegram>What's to become of the Aud? [[Worcester Telegram & Gazette]]. September 20, 2009</ref>
Since the Auditorium opened, it has been home to the [[Bay State Bombardiers]] of the [[Continental Basketball Association]] and the [[Holy Cross Crusaders]] before the [[Hart Center]] opened in 1975. It has also hosted [[Bob Dylan]]'s [[Rolling Thunder Revue]]<ref>[http://www.bjorner.com/DSN02910%201975%20Rolling%20Thunder%20Revue.htm#DSN03080 1975 Rolling Thunder Review] Accessed September 24, 2009</ref> and has served as a shelter after the [[Worcester tornado]] hit.<ref name=Telegram /> There is another small performance space known as the "Little Theater" attached to the Auditorium, which can seat 675 people, but it is currently empty as well.<ref name=Mag />
In 2013, a scene for the film [[American Hustle (2013 film)|American Hustle]] was filmed in the Worcester Auditorium.<ref>[http://www.masslive.com/news/worcester/index.ssf/2013/12/american_hustle_makes_a_hollyw.html 'American Hustle' makes a Hollywood star of Worcester] Accessed January 16, 2014</ref>
==Future== Many plans have been weighed for the future of the Auditorium. These included a canceled plan for [[Higgins Armory]] to move to the Auditorium from its current location, the creation of a [[Faneuil Hall]] style marketplace, and even the creation of a research center because of the proximity of [[Worcester Polytechnic Institute]]'s nearby Gateway Park.<ref name=Aud /> One of the largest problems with the Auditorium is that it has a flat, as opposed to a sloped audience floor, which makes it not well suited to be a modern theater.<ref name=Aud /> To convert the Auditorium to office space would cost $6.2 million, while converting it to a "museum, memorial or theater", would cost more than $12 million, much of which could be covered by tax credits.<ref name=Aud/> While some call for the demolition of the Auditorium, even a partial one that would spare the memorial wall and murals, they are a tiny minority.<ref name=Aud/> In 2016, renewed efforts<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://WorcAUD.com/|title=Worcester Memorial Auditorium|website=worcaud.com|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> were launched to rekindle interest and appreciation for the building and its 106-rank Kimball Pipe Organ.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.worcaud.com/organ/#Kimball|title=Pipe Organ – Worcester Memorial Auditorium|website=www.worcaud.com|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://WorcAUD.com/ Worcester Memorial Auditorium]

{{Orphan|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox sports team | name = Ärtemarks IF | color1 = | color2 = | logo = | logo_size = | alt = | caption = | full_name = Ärtemarks idrottsförening | nicknames = | sport = [[association football|soccer]]
[[table tennis]] (earlier) | founded = | folded = | current = | league = | conference = | division = | history = | arena = | ballpark = | stadium = | city = [[Ärtemark]], [[Sweden]] | colors = | colours = | owner = | president = | coach = | manager = | gm = | championships = | conference_titles = | division_titles = | playoff_berths = | anthem = | cheerleaders = | dancers = | mascot = | fanclub = | broadcasters = | media = | uniforms = | branches = | members = | blank_label = | blank_data = | blank_label1 = | blank_data1 = | blank_label2 = | blank_data2 = | blank_label3 = | blank_data3 = | website = }} '''Ärtemarks IF''' is a [[sports club]] in [[Ärtemark]], [[Sweden]]. The club's [[table tennis]] section won the Swedish women's national championships during the seasons of 2005–2006 and 2006–2007.{{cite web|url=http://iof1.idrottonline.se/SvenskaBordtennisforbundet/ResultatStatistik/Nationellt/SM/Allasegrare1925-2013/|title=Alla segrare|publisher=Svenska Bordtennisförbundet|language=Swedish|accessdate=16 February 2015}} The men's team qualified for the 2007–2008 Elitserien and even played som home games in the [[People's Republic of China]].{{cite web|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=125&artikel=1793452|title=Ärtemark vann andra Kinamatchen|publisher=Sveriges Radio|language=Swedish|date=22 December 2007|accessdate=16 February 2015}} In 2014, the club's table tennis activity was transferred over to [[Dals BTK]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.laget.se/artemark Ärtemarks IF] {{sv icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Artemarks IF}} [[Category:Football clubs in Sweden]] [[Category:Sport in Västra Götaland County]] [[Category:Table tennis clubs in Sweden]] {{sport-org-stub}} {{Sweden-sport-stub}}
